TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) left Australia yesterday to attend a meeting of the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific in Bangkok. The Minister for Education (Mr Fife) will act as Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs until Mr Moore's return on 15 March this year.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Government regard it as 'politically illiterate' for Parliament to require the presence before its committees of senior public servants, firstly, to give information requested by committees and, secondly, to answer questions on available policy options without expressing personal opinions or preferences?

—I know of no obstruction that the Government puts in the way of senior public servants attending committee meetings to provide factual information, that is, information that is not confidential for a particular reason. To add anything, I would need further elaboration by the Leader of the Opposition.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Does the Government consider the operation of the work test for the unemployment benefit to be satisfactory? Does the Government consider that the operation of the work test places avoidable and unnecessary strains on the Commonwealth Employment Service? Is the Government considering changes to the operation of the work test? Does the Government consider that the work test in its present form can be justified?

—The honourable senator raises a matter which is of great public interest and sometimes of great public concern. It is, however, one that is in the jurisdiction of my colleague, the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. I will ask him to give a considered reply to the question raised by the honourable senator.

—Will the Minister for National Development and Energy inform the Senate which department is responsible for policy on resources between, firstly, the exploration and mining stage and, secondly, their export? Which Minister has control, firstly, over uranium policy and, secondly, over coal policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the simplest answer would be to refer Senator Grimes to the printed administrative arrangements orders which set out quite clearly the dichotomy. As far as individual matters are concerned, national development in the obvious sense is concerned with the location and identification of the particular resources in Australia, the establishment of economic reserves, the desirable levels of conservation, the establishment of feasibility studies and pilot plant developments. Clearly, when the fully commercial stage of a resource for trade is reached the responsibility passes to other departments, as the administrative orders show. The National Energy Office of my Department has very specific administrative orders, and I draw the attention of honourable senators to them.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to uranium, general feasibility studies, such as on uranium enrichment, are covered by my Department. The Australian Safeguards Office in my Department is responsible for the auditing of nuclear safeguards. As far as coal is concerned, the actual sale of coal is basically a trade matter. However, once a policy is determined, the development of coal liquefaction and oil shale liquefaction, being an energy matter, is essentially and primarily one for my Department. Inevitably, overlapping between departments does occur-between my Department and the Department of Industry and Commerce in some cases and between my Department and the Department of Trade and Resources in others. I draw the attention of the honourable senator to the administrative orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question of the Minister. Is there any difference or conflict between him and Mr Anthony, the Minister for Trade and Resources, as to the demarcation in those areas?

—I read with interest in a newspaper that there was a conflict. Over the years some necessity has arisen for demarcation between various functions of all departments, including those two departments. All I can say is that I find no difficulty in carrying out the administrative orders which relate to my Department. Where demarcation is necessary, we seek it from the Prime Minister.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of the importance of the poppy industry to Tasmania, has the Government yet received any indication from the Government of the United States of America or its agencies of that Government's deliberations concerning the purchase of Tasmanian-grown alkaloids? Have the United States hearings been concluded? Have recommendations been made to Congress? Have there been any recent consultations with our Washington Embassy on the matter? Is any final date for decision known?

—I am aware of the interest of honourable senators from Tasmania in this matter. My advice is that the Government is well aware of the importance of the poppy industry to the Tasmanian economy, and provided advice and support to the Tasmanian Government when it appeared before the public hearing on opiates import policy in the United States of America last September. The administrative law judge who presided at that hearing handed down his report in January. He recommended that the most reasonable solution would be for a ratio of import quotas to be established between Turkey and India, on the one hand, and other exporting countries which maintain adequate controls, including Australia, on the other. The judge further recommended that allocation of quotas should be based upon world market shares during a recent representative period. The judge's finding is advisory to the United States Government and not binding. However, if adopted, it offers the prospect of access for Australian opiates to the United States market. No decision by the United States Government is expected until after the expiry of the 60-day freeze on new administrative rules, which was ordered by President Reagan on 29 January. This matter will be kept under constant notice by the Australian Government, and we will continue to press for Australian access to the United States market. If the honourable senator seeks further information he might indicate it to me.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for National Development and Energy and follows on somewhat the question asked by Senator Grimes. Does the Minister see his Department as having a major role in formulating economic policy, specifically as it relates to mineral development? Is the Minister seriously saying that there are no interdepartmental demarcation problems between the Department of the Treasury, the Department of Trade and Resources and his Department? Further, is it not true that the staff of the Department of National Development and Energy has been reduced by between 60 and 80 personnel while the Department of Trade and Resources has had an increase in staff?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact of the matter is that a department such as the one for which I have responsibility has a wide economic role and a recommending role and inevitably those roles would overlap the roles of the Department of the Treasury, the Department of Trade and Resources, the Department of Industry and Commerce and other departments. The question of the optimum usage of resources, their development and the development of energy in quantity and quality not only is a significant role for my Department but also must be shared in its activities by the Treasury and other departments. I repeat that from time to time there are matters which would involve questions of demarcation. Nevertheless, I do not find it difficult to pursue the role as laid down.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Gietzelt referred to the staff numbers in the Department. I do not have details of the precise numbers and the movements in recent months, but there has been a significant increase in the number of staff in the National Energy Office. I should have thought, therefore, that the trend would not have been as Senator Gietzelt indicated. I will obtain the figures and let him know.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to an open letter from East-West Airlines (Operations) Ltd, dated 5 March 1981, which I understand was sent to all parliamentarians and which states that the new two-airline agreement disadvantages third level commuter airlines on low to medium traffic routes throughout Australia. The letter points out that the new agreement attempts to tie down the commuter airlines to a limited and possibly declining list of approved routes and to a limited choice of imported aircraft which the commuter airlines consider not to be a fair deal for the future of the industry in Australia. Has the Minister seen the letter to which I have referred? If so, does the Minister consider that the points raised by East-West Airlines are indeed the present case? If this is true, will the Minister reconsider the new two-airline agreement with a view to allowing smaller airlines to operate with fewer restrictions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that East-West Airlines has sent an open letter to all members of parliament and I understand that it addresses East-West's position as a second level regional operator rather than the position of commuter airlines, as suggested in Senator Thomas's question. In fact, commuter operators have made little adverse comment on the two-airline agreement. Their views generally have been in overwhelming support of the improved opportunities which the new agreement provides for them. I understand that the letter also addresses the question of East-West's inability to continue to service the Sydney-Alice Springs route and seeks to attribute the blame to the existing two-airline policy.

ANSWER.PARA: The points made by East-West are inaccurate. The company is well aware that the only limitation imposed on it in respect of aircraft choice is that the aircraft suits the network over which it operates. East-West currently has approval in principle to import F28 jet aircraft for its network. The new agreement facilitates the importation of those aircraft. East-West, in its interpretation of the two-airline agreement, ignores the extent of the network it can develop, which includes all intrastate and intra-Territory services as well as services from regional centres to any other place in Australia. The only real limits placed on East-West under the new agreement are in regard to the trunk routes presently operated by Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: — I ask a supplementary question. The Minister mentioned that the second level airlines are able to import aircraft that are suitable for the route. Who decides whether they are suitable for the route?
—I imagine that that is a matter of regulation in the normal course of things and would be subject to the normal arrangements for checking out such matters.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for National Development and Energy and concerns the apparent need for some national standards for the transport of nuclear materials in Australia. On 4 December last a shipping container labelled 'Gulf Oil Corporation-Property of Gulf Nuclear, Webster, Texas' was split open after a semi-trailer accident near Port Macquarie, revealing a 60-litre drum marked 'Americium 241' and some smaller containers marked 'Caesium 137'. It is alleged that two New South Wales policemen have suffered unusual illnesses after handling the drum, which was also said to have been split open. I ask: What overall supervision is kept over the transport of nuclear materials within Australia? Is a register kept of nuclear materials imported so that their identity and degree of risk can be readily established and notified in the case of an accident?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would take a very lengthy answer to deal fully with all the questions asked because there is a wide range of nuclear materials of varying radioactivity. Senator Mason will appreciate that most of the nuclear materials moved around are of relatively low radioactivity and are for medical or industrial usage. Therefore, of course, there are different specifications for nuclear materials. The various States, as well as the Commonwealth, impose very strong health rules. I describe the situation as complex because State health laws apply to certain of the types of nuclear materials and it would be necessary for me to seek the particularities of those laws.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that the Commonwealth seeks a minimum uniformity of standards throughout the whole of Australia. In general terms, the Commonwealth is interested in the handling, particularly the interstate handling, of radioactive materials. The Commonwealth has a total interest once the material leaves Australian shores and a tracking interest for the whole of the lifetime of these materials. Although I recall the Port Macquarie incident, at this moment I do not recall the details. I will seek the actual details of the incident and in doing so I will then provide in general terms for Senator Mason the details of the safeguards that apply. I fancy that many of them would be State laws concerned with packaging and handling. I will look at the question and let the honourable senator have further information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask: Has the Government seen the extraordinary spontaneous support for anti-strike rallies? Is this support understandable in view of the fact that many strikes are deliberately intended to hurt the community as a means of gaining financial advantage for union members-behaviour that would not be tolerated from any other section of the community? Although these rallies, of course, of themselves will not do anything to improve our industrial relations, does the Minister see hope of something constructive emerging from them by encouraging the silent majority of union members to participate more in union affairs, thus getting rid of trouble making militant unions, and perhaps by making the union movement, as a whole, recognise that the day is long past when inter-union solidarity was needed in order to survive and that what is needed now is more solidarity with the community of which unions are a privileged part?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find myself somewhat surprised that the Opposition should be opposed to any form of rally. In fact, the Opposition and its spokesmen have been the most vocal proponents and, indeed, instigators of such rallies. For example, I think Mr Hawke was a keen instigator and proponent of the Medibank rally and, indeed, of a rally, some time ago, against the Budget. The question of rallies ought to find a common support on both sides of the Parliament as a means of individuals expressing their freedom of belief and their right to do so. Therefore, one would have been surprised yesterday to have heard that Labor Party members saw as divisive rallies which did not suit them but those rallies which did suit them they saw as greatly important democratic expressions. I come to the fundamentals of this situation. I and the Government observed that yesterday there were spontaneous rallies following the rally in New Zealand.

—I wish to take a point of order, Mr President. The information being given by the Minister is incorrect. Many of the people who participated in the so-called spontaneous rallies were requested to do so by employers and their wages were paid.
—No point of order is involved.

—The people of Australia have demonstrated, through radio, television and the media generally, their spontaneous support, first of all, for the concept of the young woman, Tania Harris, in her demonstration in New Zealand and subsequently for the marches that occurred yesterday.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only are members of the Opposition opposed to rallies which do not express their views, but also they are opposed to viewpoints being heard. They wish to shout down those viewpoints. The fact is that a young woman, Tania Harris of New Zealand, has caught the imagination of the free world.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister must be heard in silence.

—I am perfectly happy for the people of Australia to hear the derision of members of the Labor Party in their opposition to the types of values that Tania Harris and the young woman who led yesterday's rally stand for. If by their derision they are saying that they reject those views, they fly in the face of the beliefs and values of the people of Australia. The people have had a gutful of militant-led strikes.

—Mr President, I must raise a point of order. To make sure that the answer is in order, could you inform me how either the question or the answer deals with the portfolio that the Minister represents? Has he a brief from his Department on this matter, or is this the opinion of the Minister?
—There is no point of order.

—In brief, I believe that what Australia and New Zealand have seen, and what the free world has applauded, has been ordinary people not connected with political parties expressing spontaneously a belief that they are sick of the divisive activities of those who attempt to divide the community and to deny others the right to work, the right to travel and the right to freedom. Indeed, yesterday in Sydney a portion of the travelling public was inconvenienced by yet another strike. The Qantas Airways Ltd strike showed what the people of Australia think. I believe we owe a great debt of gratitude to the people who inspired those rallies and to those who came forward. They are expressing spontaneously the feelings of the people of Australia that strikes have been overdone. However good and valid industrial trade unionism is, politically exploited trade unionism is bad and divisive for Australia.
—I take another point of order. Mr President, if the Minister is going to continue, I draw your attention to the ruling you have given in the past about long, windy answers.
—I have reiterated that in the past. This was a direct reply to a question and that is in order. The Minister has finished his answer.

—My question is also addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. It follows that asked earlier by Senator Button which, I repeat for the benefit of the representatives of the Fourth Estate who appeared to be locked out at the time, was whether the Government regarded it as politically illiterate for Parliament to require the attendance of senior Public Service witnesses before it in certain circumstances. Does the Government specifically approve of the refusal of the Minister for Defence to allow Mr Pritchett and Admiral Synnot to appear before the Defence Sub-Committee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence? I also ask the Minister: In the light of the firm views on the subject of individual ministerial responsibility which were expressed yesterday by Mr Killen, can we expect that Minister's resignation to be given or demanded by the Government the next time there is a major procurement, or other, blunder within the Department of Defence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first nuance, I must say that I do not know what the reference to being politically illiterate means in terms of those questions. I do from time to time understand that expression here because I have examples of it. I say that because I do not know, and I would be happy to have my attention drawn to it if it would facilitate the answer.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the reasons why the Minister for Defence is taking a particular action, that is a matter on which the Minister himself will answer. But in general terms Ministers should be responsible for and answerable to the Parliament for Government policy. Public servants provide factual information on administration and are answerable to their Ministers for their administration. This was made quite clear in 'Guidelines for Official Witnesses Appearing Before Parliamentary Committees', which was tabled in the other place by the Government on 28 September 1978. The Public Service Board's 'Guidelines on Official Conduct of Commonwealth Public Servants' also deals with public comment by public servants. I think a standard procedure is laid down, which distinguishes policy from fact. I think that is well understood. If there is any further information that I can give, I will seek it out for the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is the Minister aware that the Public Service guidelines of 1978 to which he referred may have been tabled in the Parliament but were never debated by either chamber, notwithstanding promises by the Government that that would occur, and that they certainly have never been adopted by the Parliament as guidance for its committees or anyone else?

—I am not aware. I do not know whether that has happened in another place. If not, I will have a look at them. In any case, they no doubt serve as an indication of the behaviour of public servants before committees. I will certainly look them up to see whether anything is to be added.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport a question following on the question asked earlier by Senator Thomas relating to the letter that we have all received from East-West Airlines Ltd. I seek clarification from Senator Messner by asking: Is it true that the number of trunk routes specified under the present airline agreement is 40 and that, under the new agreement, this number will increase to more than 150? Is it true that, if this happens, the very viability of East-West Airlines will be at risk under the new agreement?
—I have no immediate information to confirm or to deny the matters which Senator Townley has raised. I will refer the question to the Minister and obtain a reply for the honourable senator.

—My question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister relates to the new federalism policy. The Minister will be aware of the proposal of the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Mr Everingham, to levy a new tax on the Nabalco partners operating the Gove bauxite mine and that he reportedly described the tax as taking a percentage of the company's profits calculated in terms of a formula that was fair to everyone concerned. I ask: Is it part of the federalism policy of the national Government to allow State or Territory governments to levy a company tax additional to that levied by the Commonwealth in the same way as it proposes to allow room for such governments to levy personal income tax additional to that levied by the Commonwealth?
—I am not familiar with the details of Mr Everingham's proposal, either the constitutional details or other details regarding the levying of a company tax.
—Have a go.

—Thank you very much, Senator McAuliffe. Your support for my ability to do so extempore I appreciate enormously. However, I will not. I propose to refer the question to the Treasurer to seek his more expert advice.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The question was not directed to the Treasurer for any technical advice. It was directed to the Prime Minister in respect of the new federalism policy which has had its strongest proponent in the Parliament in the person of Senator Carrick. I repeat the substance of the question: Under the new federalism policy is there room for State or Territory governments to levy a company tax additional to that levied by the Commonwealth and parallel to the often-spoken of proposed ability of the States to levy personal income tax additional to that levied by the Commonwealth?

—At this moment, the federalism policy has very clear definitions. It is based upon the States receiving some 39.87 per cent of the revenue raised as personal income tax by the Commonwealth. The States are able to apply either a rebate or a surcharge to that. They are able to raise a wide range of indirect taxes. I repeat that I am not aware of the technical or other capacity of the States to levy company tax. Because I am unaware of that, I will seek information from either the Prime Minister or the Treasurer.

—I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I do so following the question of Senator Evans. Is it not a fact that during the term of office of the Whitlam Government senior public servants were called before this Senate and, when questioned, declined to answer any of those questions? Is it not a fact that that was done at the direction of their Ministers?
—I think the Hansard records of this place confirm the information Senator Young has given.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, deals with a matter raised previously by Senator Mason. I refer to the overturning of a transport vehicle carrying a 60-litre drum labelled 'Danger-radioactive-Americium 241'. The transport vehicle was also carrying smaller containers labelled 'Caesium 137' and foodstuffs. When the Minister carries out the investigation requested by Senator Mason will he find out what is the role of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission at Lucas Heights whenever accidents involving radioactive materials occur? Is it a fact that radio messages were sent to Sydney police headquarters at 7.30 a.m. requesting it to contact Lucas Heights to find out how to handle the radioactive materials and that the message came back: 'We do not know. Ring back at 9 o'clock when the Atomic Energy Commission opens'.
—Never on Sunday.

—Never on Sunday. Never before the children. If this is an accurate report, does it mean that there was no duty officer at Lucas Heights who could provide immediate advice in a radiation emergency outside business hours or does it mean that police headquarters did not know how to make contact with the responsible officer of the Atomic Energy Commission outside business hours? Finally, who is responsible for tracing the food which was transferred from this vehicle to another vehicle by salvage workers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a fairly lengthy reply to Senator Mason, I indicated that the daily handling of radioactive materials, particularly for medical or industrial purposes, is essentially and predominantly a matter for the States and State laws. I say that without seeking to resile at all from the overall responsibilities of the Commonwealth. I did say that I would seek to obtain information for Senator Mason as to that accident. Indeed, there have been several of these accidents. At Mascot airport a container of radioactive materials-medical isotopes, I think-fell off the pallet of an aircraft-unloading vehicle and was run over. Those materials were dealt with very quickly by a combination of advice from the Australian Atomic Energy Commission and the State health authorities.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not aware at all of any attempt by the police to get in touch with the Atomic Energy Commission. Basically I would have thought that the Port Macquarie situation would have been dealt with by the State health authorities. I will look at the matter to see whether, in fact, such a situation did arise. People are always on duty at the Atomic Energy Commission because, of course, the reactor is functioning 24 hours a day. On that basis there are always people on duty. I am not aware of any such matter. Senator O'Byrne indicated that there was food on the truck. Again, I would think that that is a State matter, but it is important. I will look it up and see whether I can get the information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister satisfied that State legislation and regulations are sufficient to cover emergencies such as this? Will the Commonwealth take some action to ensure that it has overall legislation to deal with such emergencies?

—During the whole of the uranium debate in this place the indications were that the Commonwealth was discussing with the States a code of safety for the handling of materials. Indeed, we regarded a particular safety code as a minimum and I believe it is also accepted by all States as a minimum. Senator O'Byrne will realise that every day in the week these nuclear materials are being handled at hospitals and in industries. Of course, he will recall the incident which occurred when a measuring gauge was being sent by accident in scrap material to Singapore.
—This was an accident, too.

—Yes, they happen quite commonly. That is not to say that that should in any way disguise the importance-I acknowledge this to Senator O'Byrne-of making the most stringent rules which are to be observed. I have no reason to believe that the State laws are not as stringent as we would desire. I will look at the matter and if, indeed, there is any need for further action I will make sure that action is taken.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. Has the attention of the Minister been drawn to the latest report of the Australian Research Grants Committee-that for 1981? Does the report show that for the first time since the inception of the scheme in 1966 the number of grants made under this scheme has actually fallen-from 1,526 last year to only 1,453 this year? Does the report go on to show that, whilst in 1980 some 112 projects were judged worthy of support but in fact could not be funded, this number grew to 296 this year? Does this indicate that, despite commendable progress made in increasing research funds in areas such as medical research, energy research, industrial research and productivity grants, there is still a significant need for more money to be committed to research grants made through the ARGC mechanism? Will the significant figures revealed in this latest report be borne in mind by the Government as it starts to formulate its policies for the next Budget?

—I accept the figures showing the number of grants and so forth cited by Senator Puplick. However, the position is that the Australian Research Grants Committee was established in 1965 to provide opportunities for first class work and to stimulate research. In 1978 the Australian Science and Technology Council reported on the basic scientific funding in Australia and recommended that funds be increased in real terms but that emphasis be given to excellence. I understand that that report of ASTEC has had some influence on the reduction in the number of grants referred to by Senator Puplick because the Committee has had regard to that special recommendation that emphasis be given to excellence in regard to ARGC grants. Furthermore, in recent years the Government has stimulated research in other fields, specifically through the Australian Marine Science and Technology Research Scheme and the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Scheme. There are other calls on government research funds in the scientific area. The matters that have been mentioned by Senator Puplick will be given consideration by the Government in the Budget context.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. It was reported in the Weekend Australian dated 24-25 January 1981 that the Government was planning to spend up to $48m in the next two years on business jet aircraft to replace the Canberra bombers presently undertaking photographic and survey work. It was also stated that by following this policy the Government would save millions of dollars. I ask: Would not the Government save more millions of dollars and, at the same time, create employment for some of the half a million people out of work, if it were to forgo the purchase of those sophisticated status symbols and concentrate on upgrading our own Nomad aircraft which I imagine would be ideal for photographic and survey work?
—I am unaware of the report to which Senator McIntosh refers. I will refer the matter to the Minister for Defence and ask him to provide further comment on the matter.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Does the Minister recall that the former Minister for Home Affairs and Environment stated on 12 December 1980 that the next meeting of the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council would consider the boundaries for the proposed Cairns section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park? When does the Government expect to be able to make an announcement on these boundary proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I have not seen the statement by the former Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, I do have some information on this matter. I understand that on 1 May last year the Prime Minister stated that he expected that by the end of the year 20 per cent of the Great Barrier Reef would be in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. This obviously implied that the Cairns section of the Park would have been proclaimed at that stage.

ANSWER.PARA: At the third meeting of the Ministerial Council, on 1 August, there was an agreement to invite the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to examine and bring forward to the next meeting of the Council proposals for the boundaries of the proposed Cairns section of the Park and the full implications of those boundaries. The Queensland State election, taking place when it did, forced the cancellation of the Ministerial Council meeting which was to discuss some of these matters. The Queensland Government is presently being consulted on the date of the next meeting of the Council. Until that date is settled and until that meeting takes place, it is not possible to proceed with the completion of the declaration to which the honourable senator refers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. By way of preface, I refer to media reports of today in which Mr William Clifford of the Australian Institute of Criminology is reported as claiming that Australian Aborigines might have the highest rate of imprisonment in the world. Is the Minister aware that 80 per cent of all offences and almost 100 per cent of serious offences committed by Aboriginal people in the Alice Springs area are alcohol related? Is the Minister aware that no detoxification centre and no psychiatric services for Aboriginal people are available in Alice Springs, or in Darwin as I understand it. If the Minister agrees that it is negligent to allow people, whose basic problem is alcoholism, to go to gaol where they receive no treatment for their problem, what steps is he prepared to take to establish detoxification and psychiatric services for Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the report in the Age this morning-I do not know whether it appeared in other newspapers-in which Mr William Clifford made an estimate that Aboriginal people might have the highest imprisonment rate in the world and in which he estimated a certain rate of imprisonment. He went on to suggest a number of possible reasons why this might be so. I remind the honourable senator that they included the fact that Aboriginals had social problems which brought them into more conflict with the law. The answer to the question which has been put by the honourable senator is contained in that supposition by Mr Clifford.

ANSWER.PARA: The alcohol related problems which Aboriginals manifest are themselves an indication of social disintegration and of unmet social needs. Whilst I will look sympathetically at any applications which are made to me through appropriate funding mechanisms for rehabilitation programs or other intervention programs, I suggest to the honourable senator that it is more appropriate for us to look at improving the underlying conditions which lead to this high rate of alcohol abuse among Aboriginals in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister prepared to allow the situation to continue in Alice Springs where there is no detoxification unit and where no psychiatric services are available?
—I am willing to undertake an investigation of the situation. I will come back to the honourable senator when I have more information.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. During a radio debate and talkback session with Senator Susan Ryan on radio station 2CN Canberra yesterday the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Mr Paul Everingham, indicated that the Northern Territory Government's five-year plan to upgrade and carry out essential capital works on Aboriginal settlements was in jeopardy for, while the Northern Territory Government was funding to its limit, sufficient Federal moneys were not available. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the present position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The five-year plan in the Northern Territory has been formulated by the Northern Territory Government and the Chief Minister for the Northern Territory and has not been the subject of any agreement between that Government and the Commonwealth Government. Human Rights Commission Bill 1981

The purpose of this Bill is to establish a Commonwealth Human Rights Commission. The Commission will promote the observance of human rights throughout Australia within the limits of Commonwealth power. In co-operation with the States on human rights matters the Commission will assist the Government in discharging its international obligations in the cause of human rights. Our intention to introduce this legislation was foreshadowed in the Government's policy speech prior to the last election. The most recent attempt by this Government to have Parliament approve a human rights commission foundered because of a lack of agreement between the Senate and the other House on what became known as the Simon amendment, and was related to the rights of the child before as well as after birth. The Government has arrived at a formula, included in this Bill, which it believes will be acceptable to both those who voted for and those who voted against the amendments made by the other House. I shall return to this matter in a moment.

Since the Human Rights Commission Bill 1979 was debated in the Senate, several events have transpired which only add to the need for effective human rights machinery in Australia. In August of last year, Australia ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. To date 65 countries have become parties to this covenant, many of which have established their own special forms of machinery to promote and protect human rights. The measure now before us, and the Commission that would be established under it, will help Australia to discharge the obligations it has assumed under the covenant.

Last August, as well, the Government established the Human Rights Bureau as an interim measure pending creation of a human rights commission. Recently, the Bureau has begun to receive representations from the public in the form of complaints, requests for assistance, and requests for information in the general field of human rights. The Bureau has also made significant progress in establishing links with non-government organisations in the human rights field. It is apparent, however, that there is a need for more effective machinery to promote human rights in Australia than is available through the Bureau, and it is the object of the Bill to provide this machinery. The Commission will not be a large undertaking. Its emphasis will be on quality. Its annual cost is currently estimated at about $850,000, to which will be added the cost of the Office of the Commissioner for Community Relations-estimated at $350,000 in 1980-81.

The main provisions of the Bill are the same as those in the Bill approved by the Senate in November 1979. As such, they have already been the subject of considerable discussion and debate. I intend in this speech, therefore, to refer to and explain only those changes from the 1979 Bill that are found in the present measure. The only change of significance is that the charter of the Commission has been extended to three additional international instruments. As with the previous Bill, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights will be the primary point of reference for the Commission. However, in response to the concern expressed by many members in both Houses during the debate on the Simon amendment about the rights of both children and handicapped persons, the Commission will also be required to have regard, in areas of Commonwealth responsibility, for the rights of these groups as recognised in three international declarations, each of which has been supported by Australia. The three declarations are the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, 1959; the Declaration on the Rights of the Mentally Retarded, 1971; and the Declaration on the Rights of the Disabled, 1975.

The Declaration of the Rights of the Child recognises that the child, by reason of his physical and mental immaturity, needs special safeguards and care, including appropriate legal protection, before as well as after birth. The declaration calls upon men and women everywhere, on voluntary organisations and on governments to strive for the observance of the rights of the child which it proclaims. The rights include the right to special protection to enable the child to develop fully; the right to enjoy the benefits of social security, including adequate pre-natal and post-natal care; and the rights to education and to protection from cruelty and exploitation.

Similarly, the two declarations concerned with the rights of physically and intellectually handicapped call for national and international action to protect the rights they declare. The rights of the intellectually handicapped include the right to be accorded as far as possible the same rights as other persons; the right to economic security and a decent standard of living; and the right to protection from exploitation, abuse, and degrading treatment. The rights of the physically handicapped include the right to the same civil and political rights as other persons; the right to respect for their human dignity; the right to measures to enable them to become as self-reliant as possible; and the rights to medical and other treatment and to economic and social security and a decent level of living.

The three declarations I have just been describing do not represent commitments in international law, as does the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. But they express important aspirations, and we are proposing that the Commission should monitor, and report on, the way in which Commonwealth departments and agencies, and activities generally in the Australian Capital Territory, are conforming with them. The three declarations are defined in clause 3 of the Bill, and are included in the definition of 'human rights' in the same clause. There are consequential amendments, chiefly in clause 31, which envisage the declaration of further international instruments as part of the Commission's charter.

During debate on the 1979 Bill and in the ensuing months, comments have been made about certain aspects of the 1979 Bill that are repeated in the present Bill. Because they are apparently the source of some concern, I should like to discuss three of those criticisms. The first is that the scope of the proposed Commission would extend only to laws of the Commonwealth and the Territories-except the Northern Territory-and actions or procedures under such laws. The Commission's mandate will not extend to State or Northern Territory laws or actions or procedures of State and Northern Territory authorities. However, clause 11 of the Bill provides for a range of co-operative arrangements to be entered into with the States and it is my expectation that this mechanism will be fully used.

The ministerial meeting on human rights will continue to exercise a role at top policy level in considering issues which require consultation between the various levels of government and in promoting generally the cause of human rights in Australia. Accordingly, this Bill manifests the Government's continuing commitment to co-operative federalism, which is already developing well in the human rights field. The second criticism levelled at the 1979 Bill is that the proposed Commission would incorporate the Office of the Commissioner for Community Relations. Non-government organisations in the human rights field have particularly voiced this concern. It is motivated by a fear that the work done by the Commissioner for Community Relations will somehow be interrupted or curtailed. My hope and expectation in fact is quite the opposite. Let me emphasise, as I did when the previous Bill was before the Senate, that the Commissioner for Community Relations will continue to carry out the complaint-handling and conciliation functions associated with administration of the Racial Discrimination Act. Further, the added resources of the Commission will be available to assist as required in the important task of combating racial discrimination, and there will be recourse, as there was not previously, to the Meeting of Ministers on Human Rights on racial discrimination matters.

The Government is confident, therefore, that establishing the Commission will not make less effective the role of the Commissioner for Community Relations in dealing with complaints of racial discrimination. Thirdly, there have been criticisms that the Human Rights Commission is being given inadequate powers-that it has no machinery for enforcement of its findings. That criticism represents a misunderstanding of the essential purpose of the Commission. The purpose of the Commission is to promote discussion and understanding of human rights in the community generally and to recommend to the Government and to Parliament changes in law or practice required to bring that law and practice into line with human rights as defined by the International Covenant or other human rights instruments. For its job, the Commission has been given adequate powers to obtain papers, to call witnesses, to conduct hearings and to make reports. A survey of institutions with similar functions in Australia and overseas shows that the Commission is as well, or better, endowed with powers than other bodies having similar functions.

What the critics of the Commission suggest is that it should have some kind of court-like powers of enforcement. In the view of the Government, this may be a possible step for the future, but it is not the next step, which is the establishment of the Commission. It is only when the Parliament has laid down laws relating to human rights in a particular area-for example relating to racial discrimination-that the normal law enforcement machinery should be considered. Even there, the clear cut and authoritative decisions of the courts may not be the correct way to proceed, at any rate in the early stages of the operation of the law. The promotion of human rights in this country will be achieved more through education, through finding new balances of interests and through conciliation than through firm measures of enforcement. In closing, I should like to refer to the final paragraph of my second reading speech for the 1979 Bill. The thoughts and hopes expressed are as current and important today as they were then. I said:

Human rights are about the protection of individuals. I believe, and the Government believes, that in an era of social change in which governments exercise wide powers and corporations and large institutions greatly influence the lives of individuals, it is important to have an agency that is active in the protection and promotion of the rights of individuals. We see in the world around us too many occasions where the rights of individuals are cruelly violated. The purpose of the Human Rights Commission, and of the machinery associated with it, is to help Australia maintain its excellent record in the protection of human rights, and progressively to develop a better and more comprehensive recognition and observance of the rights of every individual in our community, regardless of financial standing and whatever his or her race, age, sex, religion or status.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Racial Discrimination Amendment Bill 1981

This Bill is a purely technical Bill, and is associated with the Human Rights Commission Bill 1981, which I have just introduced. Shipping Registration Bill 1981

The Shipping Registration Bill is an important step forward in the development of Australia's status as an independent nation. The right of a country to determine the conditions for the grant of its nationality to ships is fundamental to its national sovereignty. In international law the nationality of ships is determined by the flag they are entitled to fly. It is also customary to require at least the larger ships to be registered in order to secure the right to fly the national flag. The present law governing the registration of ships in Australia was enacted by the Parliament at Westminster 87 years ago. Indeed, it is contained in Part I of the Merchant Shipping Act 1894.

Originally that law applied throughout the British Empire on the basis that a ship was a British ship if it was owned by a British subject or corporation in any part of the Empire. The Act required all British ships to be registered except certain small ships of less than 15 tons carrying capacity. Registration could be effected at any British port of registry throughout the Empire and this entailed the entry of particulars of the ship and of its owners and mortgagees in the register at the port. The registrar at the port was required to transmit returns at regular intervals to the Registrar-General of Shipping and Seamen at Cardiff and in that way a complete record of all British ships was built up. However this procedure has been abandoned in recent years.

From the commencement of the Statute of Westminster 1931, the various member countries of the British Commonwealth were free to repeal the Merchant Shipping Act 1984 and to establish their own shipping registers. However, under an agreement negotiated in 1931 the laws of each country were required to adopt a common status of 'British ship' and to follow closely the provisions of Part I of the Merchant Shipping Act 1894. By mutual agreement in 1978 the British Commonwealth Merchant Shipping Agreement 1931 was rescinded by all member countries. Australia is the only major independent member of the Commonwealth, other than Britain itself, to have continued to operate under the Merchant Shipping Act system. The stage has now been reached where it is essential that we put an end to this anachronism. The Commonwealth countries have recently agreed on common principles for the future operation of their own shipping registers. In accordance with those principles the United Kingdom is expected to confine the Merchant Shipping Act system to Britain, to ships more than 50 per cent owned by residents of Britain or companies based in Britain. It is understood that the adoption by Australia of its own national system will simplify the task being undertaken by the British authorities.

The principles underlying this Bill have been the subject of extensive discussion with the States and the Northern Territory in the Marine and Ports Council of Australia. Their views were taken into account in the framing of the legislation. In recent discussions in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, agreement has been reached on the form of the clause relating to the preservation of State and Territory laws and that revised clause appears in the Bill.

I turn now to a description of the main features of the Bill. Firstly the Bill repeals Part I of the Merchant Shipping Act 1894 insofar as it is part of the law of Australia, thus terminating Australia's reliance on the British legislation and clearing the way for the adoption of an appropriate Australian system. Secondly, the provisions spell out the ships that are eligible for Australian registration, either on a compulsory or on a voluntary basis. The main elements are: Defence Force ships are excluded and registration is compulsory only for Australian-owned commercial ships of 12 metres or more in length, other than certain government ships, fishing vessels and pleasure craft; Australian-owned ships for which registration is not compulsory may be registered on a voluntary basis and also ships under 12 metres in length that are owned or operated by Australian citizens or residents may be registered; and registration is also permitted in the case of foreign-owned ships that are demise chartered to Australian interests.

The procedures for registration, including the evidence of ownership required, the division of property in the ship into 64 shares, issuing of registration certificates and of provisional certificates and the naming of marking of the ship have been made broadly comparable with the British system to ensure that the changeover from that system to the Australian system can be effected with a minimum of inconvenience for shipowners. The same can be said of the provisions of Part III of the Bill which deal with transfer and transmission of title and the registration and priority of mortgages.

The flag proposals for Australian ships were arrived at after considerable public discussion. In the Australian Merchant Navy there was strong support for the continued use of the Australian Red Ensign. Therefore it is proposed to declare the Australian Red Ensign the national colours for Australian merchant ships. Regarding other ships the general opinion was that they should be allowed to fly either the Australian National Flag or the Australian Red Ensign. This was accepted on the condition that the two flags would not be flown simultaneously. Complementary amendments to the Flags Act 1953 and the Navigation Act 1912 are necessary. The Flags Amendment Bill and the Navigation Amendment Bill are being introduced for that purpose. Apart from these flags which until now have been covered by a mixture of British and Australian laws, the British Admiralty has issued individual warrants to certain members of some 16 yacht clubs in Australia, authorising them to wear the British Blue Ensign, either undefaced or in a defaced form. The British Blue Ensign is similar to the Australian National Flag but without the stars. Approximately 400 Australian yacht owners have been issued with such warrants. This causes some difficulty as under the Geneva Convention on the High Seas 1958, to which Australia is a party, ships have the nationality of the country whose flag they are entitled to fly.

These international requirements apply particularly to the high seas. It is possible to permit departure from the Convention requirement in the Australian territorial sea and internal waters. In view of the concern expressed by yacht owners who presently have Blue Ensign warrants, the Bill will allow them to continue to fly that flag in Australian waters so long as British law allows them to fly the flag. The Bill also preserves the use of the flag of a State or Territory in Australian waters and contains provisions in respect of flag rights for unregistered Australian ships.

The provisions of Parts IV and V of the Bill set out the broad administrative arrangements for the establishment and operation of the Australian Register of Ships. In this area there are some significant departures from the present system. The proposed Australian system is basically a centralised system in that there will be only one register. The Bill provides that the Register and copies of the Register or such part or parts of the Register as the Minister directs shall be kept at such places as the Minister directs. It also provides that there shall be at such places in Australia as the Minister determines, an Australian Shipping Registration Office and such number of branch registration offices as the Minister determines. This is a flexible arrangement and it enables a certain amount of decentralisation. However, it does not suffer from the disadvantage of the present system in Australia under which there is a seperate register at each of 20 ports of registry and the complete record of all ships registered in Australia is not available at any one place. One consequence of that change is that there will be no ports of registry as such. However, because of the importance of the port of registry concept for legal and other purposes, the Bill makes provision for the adoption of a concept of home port for each ship and the regulations will spell this out in greater detail including the practice of continuing to mark the port on the ship's stern.

Part VI of the Bill contains a number of miscellaneous provisions including power to remove unqualified ships from the Register and the provision of penalties for offences. It also includes the clauses relating to the preservation of State and Territory laws and the review of decisions of the Minister or the Registrar by the courts or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Finally, the Bill contains transitional provisions that have been framed in such a way as to minimise any inconvenience to the owners and mortgagees of ships registered in Australia under the Merchant Shipping Act. On the commencement date the existing registers will be deemed to form part of the Australian Register and no further action will be required of owners or mortgagees in order to effect the transition to the Australian Register. The Australian Register will of course make use of modern procedures, equipment and documentation and ships will be progressively transferred over to the new documentation after the commencement date. As I mentioned this Bill is an important step forward in the development of our status as an independent nation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Flags Amendment Bill 1981

The Flags Amendment Bill is a small Bill to complement the Shipping Registration Bill 1981 and the Navigation Amendment Bill 1981. The only amendment of substance is made to Schedule 1 of the Flags Act 1953, which contains the description of the Australian National Flag. The new wording to be inserted in that Schedule will describe both the Australian National Flag and the Australian Red Ensign. This is necessary because at present the description of the Australian Red Ensign is partly contained in section 406 of the Navigation Act 1912, which is being repealed by the Navigation Amendment Bill 1981.

One consequence of this adjustment is that the present reference to the British Blue Ensign in describing the Australian National Flag is removed. This means that the description of the Australian flags stands on its own and does not rely on reference to the flag of another country. Other changes proposed in the amending Bill are of a drafting nature only. I refer honourable senators also to the remarks I made in my second reading speech on the Shipping Registration Bill on the question of flags to be worn by Australian ships. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Navigation Amendment Bill 1981

The principal purpose of the Navigation Amendment Bill 1981 is to amend the Navigation Act so as to accord with the proposed Shipping Registration Act. The Shipping Registration Bill which I have just introduced provides for the prescribing of national colours to be flown by Australian ships and therefore the Navigation Amendment Bill repeals an overlapping provision in the Navigation Act.

Many provisions of the Navigation Act refer to British ships and, in particular, the whole of Part II is expressed to apply only to British ships except where a contrary intention appears. These references to British ships are being replaced with references to ships registered in Australia under the Shipping Registration Act or otherwise having a close connection with Australia. Schedule 2 to the Bill contains many of these consequential amendments. Australia's withdrawal from the British Commonwealth Merchant Shipping Agreement 1931, which took effect in 1979, is an added reason for making these changes. Provisions of the Navigation Act relating to the tonnage measurement of ships refer to ships registered in Australia under the Merchant Shipping Act. There is a similar reference in section 411 of the Act. These provisions are being replaced with references to the Shipping Registration Act.

A second purpose of the Bill is to update the offence provisions of the Navigation Act and to ensure that the penalties prescribed are appropriate to present day conditions. These amendments are made by clause 44 and Schedule 3 to the Bill. Some of the amendments affect sections of the principal Act introduced in 1979 or 1980 that are not yet in force. Special commencement arrangements are required for these provisions and are contained in sub-clause 2 (5) and Schedule 1 to the Bill.

The general purpose of these amendments is to update the level of pecuniary penalties in line with present money values. At the same time opportunity has been taken to repeal offences that are not relevant to present day conditions or that are now covered by the general criminal law. Other improvements are the provision of higher pecuniary penalties for offences by corporations and the provision of indictable offences that can be dealt with summarily if the parties and the court all agree.

The Bill also makes a number of minor adjustments that are considered to be appropriate at this time. An example of this is contained in clause 6 which adjusts the Minister's power of delegation. Another example is in paragraph 3 (2) (c) of the Bill which adjusts the definition of 'ship' in relation to off-shore industry mobile units that are not self-propelled. Finally, the Bill proposes to insert into the Act a power to exempt ships from one or more of the provisions of the Act where the ships only come within the jurisdiction of the Act infrequently-for example, where they have to undergo a single interstate voyage. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Currency Amendment Bill will not be opposed by the Opposition. It authorises the minting of silver coins with a face value of $10. The price at which the coins will be sold when they are ultimately minted will be determined closer to the time of release. This practice follows a precedent established by the Government last year when two gold coins-one being a bullion coin and the other a currency coin-were minted and sold by the Government at prices substantially higher than the value of the coins' metal content and the cost of minting. Indeed, it is reported by different sources that the total profits on the transaction will be between $10m and $15m. I do not know whether this is one of the exercises the Government has in mind in accordance with its obsession to reduce the Budget deficit but it will certainly have that effect.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess that if people want to pay well above the value of the metal content of the coins, there is no good reason why the government should not take their money. Indeed, it could be seen as a system of voluntary taxation. As such, it would not be all that far removed from the system of taxation over which this Government has presided for many years, at least in relation to the very rich. Taxation for the very rich is largely a voluntary matter because of the Government's continuing refusal to take the only effective action which can be taken against tax avoidance-given the Byzantine rulings and reasoning of the High Court of Australia-that is, the introduction of retrospective legislation. Since the Government has closed off and continues to close off that option, taxpaying becomes voluntary for the very rich. Therefore, it is quite appropriate that de facto taxpaying in the form of purchasing these coins ought to be extended to the lower income groups as well as to the very rich.

I said that a precedent had been set last year with the issue of the gold coins. I hope that the other precedents associated with the issue of gold coins will not be followed with the silver coin. One which will is the precedent of making money out of the issues. In particular, I refer to the 70,000 Australians who ordered coins which the Government will not be able to supply and also to the number-an intermediate number but probably several thousand-whose money has been accepted by the Government for the coins, the delivery of which was not effected for a very long time.

Indeed, according to some Press reports on the Government's failure either to deliver the coins on time or to deliver them at all, it would seem that the coin distribution exercise is the greatest farce that we have seen since the Liberal Party's great Khemlani's suitcase chase of 1975. I cite as an example the Sydney Sun-Herald of 8 February this year which states:
Deliveries of the gold koala coins are now months behind schedule and at least two consignments have been lost or stolen.
Later, the report reads:
-one in Brisbane and one in Melbourne. Police are still searching for the 100 coins involved.

Although we entirely approve of the Government's exercise in painlessly extracting money from the public in this way, our hope is that the Government can organise the exercise more efficiently in this instance than it did in the gold coin exercise.

Another irony associated with the issue of the gold coins is that, although some 70,000 Australians had ordered the coins and were unable, because of the Government's inefficiency to procure them, the issue of Overseas Trading of 27 February, which is the journal issued by the Department of Trade and Resources, contains an item boasting about the fact that some 8,000 gold coins will be taken up in the United States. The article states:
Australia's newly minted $200 gold coin has scored a sell-out success in the USA. All of an issue of 8000 of the coins was taken up within days of its recent release to the American public.
The US shipment consisted of 2000 individually struck 'proof' coins, in presentation packs, selling at $310 each, and 6000 'uncirculated' coins, also in presentation packs, selling at $240 each.

Release of the coins was announced at a press conference in New York by the Senior Trade Commissioner, Mr M. G. B. Coultas, with the Royal Australian Mint's representative in the USA Mr John Van Emden.

As both a collector's item and a speculative investment gold coins have generated a high level of interest in the USA. Since gold coin sales started in the USA six years ago, for instance, 29 million Krugerands have been sold.

I suppose the Department of Trade and Resources is to be commended for what is apparently a painless and profitable distribution of coins in the US. It is a pity that the Government could not organise the distribution in Australia as efficiently as it was organised overseas. One might also add that the Government is under some obligation or ought to consider itself under some obligation to supply the Australian demand before supplying an overseas demand. For the reasons that I have stated, the Opposition supports the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill will not be opposed by the Opposition. It makes a number of amendments to the Dairying Research Act, nearly all of which could be regarded as trivial. For example, the name of the body controlling research funds has been changed from the Dairying Research Committee to the Australian Dairy Research Committee and the number of representatives of producers of milk used for manufacturing purposes has been increased from three to four. The Bill also contains an innovation which the Opposition welcomes. The Government has been introducing this provision into all recent legislation of this type. I refer to the requirement for members of committees and boards of this type to disclose any pecuniary interests they may have which could lead to conflict of interest situations. I suggest that the transcript of recent proceedings of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations would provide ample evidence of the need for such a provision, if the need were not already apparent.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to take advantage of the opportunity by making a few generalised comments about the Australian dairying industry. Firstly and most importantly-this is recognised by anyone who takes a serious interest in the subject-the manufacturing sector of the dairying industry is in a much better shape, a much healthier condition, than it was a decade ago. In dairying industry establishment circles and in those conservative political circles that take any interest in such matters, it is fashionable to attribute this fact to cult figures, such as the former Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation, Mr Webster, and the President of United Dairyfarmers of Victoria and present Deputy Chairman of the Corporation, Mr Pyle, or some favoured son, such as Ronald Anderson, the publisher of Primary Industry Newsletter.

The critical factor to which the healthier condition of the manufacturing sector of the dairying industry must be attributed-I would not deny the Mr Webster played some part in this regard in the early stages-is the structural changes which have taken place within the last decade. I refer to the reorientation of the industry from the production of an end product for which the market was dying-that is, butter-to the production of those end products for which the market is growing, principally cheese and wholemilk powder. Those structural changes were not precipitated by people such as Mr Pyle or Mr Webster; they were precipitated by the legislative changes made by the Labor Government in 1974 and 1975. Those changes were vilified at the time, particularly by the Country Party under the various names by which it is known in the States, and were not accepted gratefully by the dairying industry establishment of the day. But ultimately they have been shown to be highly advantageous to the dairying industry, as the Labor Government of the time, with its more rational approach to agricultural policy-making, appreciated would be the case. Had it not been for the election of a Labor Government there is no real doubt, given the propensity of the Liberal Party to cave in to National Country Party demands and pressures on this and other matters, that the dairying industry would have been in a much worse condition today.

In the last 12 months there has been a great deal of loose talk from influential people in the industry about the decline in the numbers of dairy farmers, which have roughly halved in the last decade, being a tragedy. The obvious response to these people is that it is just as well for those who are still dairy farmers that this number has halved. Had it not halved in the way that it did the net income of the industry would not be very much greater than it is now and it would have to be spread around almost twice as many dairy farmers, with obvious implications for the average income of dairy farmers. People who have indulged in such loose talk either are unaware of the constraints which the industry faces or are concerned more with maintaining the income of dairy farmer organisations, such as United Dairy Farmers of Victoria, than with the welfare of the dairy farmer.

There has also been an alarmist campaign about the alleged horrific prospect of butter being imported from New Zealand. I might say that the comment in the agricultural Press on this matter, whilst it has been lengthy and at times highly emotional, has not been very enlightening. It seemed likely a few months ago, but it now seems less likely, that although Australia is a significant net exporter of butter-we will export perhaps 20,000 or 30,000 tonnes of butter this year-local supplies will be inadequate to meet local demands. Given that the price is significantly higher on the domestic market than it is on the free world market, the fact that manufacturers were selling on the export market in preference to the higher priced local market was superficially a mystery. It was possible that they had inadvisedly entered into longer term contracts to supply export markets at stated prices, not anticipating the way in which prices would move. After several weeks of reading about these matters in the agricultural Press and of reading the not infrequently verbose and emotive comments of dairying industry leaders, I was finally informed by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics that the problem was that in order to secure a captive home market earlier legislation-an Act of I think, 1977-required that a levy be imposed on all butter production. That is fairly well known. That revealed nothing new to people who were taking any interest at all in the industry. But that levy exceeded the market differential between the price of butter in Australia and the free on board export price. In other words, because butter prices overseas had risen, although still substantially below the prevailing Australian domestic price, they were above the Australian domestic price net of levy. In those circumstances it was very clear that the appropriate response was to reduce the levy on domestic sales. The Government has not done that. I wonder why it has not?

Disregarding that example of inefficiency, incompetence and negligence on the part of governmental authorities, there is no reason to become hysterical about the prospect of butter being imported from New Zealand to meet shortfalls in the local supply if Australian dairy products can be sold overseas in a different form at more profitable prices. Indeed, it would be a completely rational thing to do. Any given quantity of milk, at least in the longer term, can be converted to butter, cheese, wholemilk powder and a number of other dairy products. If the market for Australian cheese overseas, for example, provided a higher return than the Australian domestic market provided for the same milk if converted to butter, any sensible dairying industry operator would supply the overseas market. If New Zealanders are happy to supply the Australian butter market at prices less remunerative than the export cheese market is to Australian dairy farmers, then there is no reason why we should not import the butter.

It seems, of course, highly unlikely that the New Zealand dairy industry would be so inept that it would forgo higher priced markets for cheese overseas in order to supply what is effectively a lower priced market for butter in Australia. At least it seems highly unlikely that the New Zealand dairy industry would be so inept as to do that for any considerable length of time. I suspect, however that the real cause of what was seen to be the problem, that is the apparent likely shortfall of production in Australian butter for the domestic market, was the Government's negligence in failing to adjust the levy on domestic sales to a more appropriate level, thereby allowing the market situation to drift into the position where the price realised on the free market exceeded the price on the domestic market, net of levy. I hope that such ineptitude and inefficiency will be less common in the future than it has been.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too am not opposing the Dairying Research Amendment Bill 1981. In effect it is not the simple Bill that it may appear because it is now quite an important Bill to one of Australia's vital industries. This industry was once a major export industry and it has now become basically domestic. As such we have reached the stage where the industry needs to be retained for all the range of economic and strategic reasons that go with providing food for the nation. In 1976 we took the heavy approach towards rationalising the dairy industry and this has achieved most of what was proposed. It has worked quite well through the production sector and while some mistakes have been made it has been quite satisfactory. The farmers in the production area have done well. Over this period they have become very efficient and are now well equipped, well stocked and are certainly striving to do even better.

SPEECH.PARA: During this period we have seen the commencement of a tendency towards larger farms, of corporate dairying and a slight drift away from the traditional family farm. With this we have come upon a somewhat newer breed of dairymen who are better educated, more businesslike, more interested in getting further ahead and in achieving more and wider research. We need only look into the Dairying Research Committee's report to see what it is all about. The report states:

The broad objective of the scheme is to raise productivity and enhance the welfare of the Industry. In accordance with the requirements of the Dairying Research Act 1972, expenditure from research funds should be within the following categories and directly or indirectly related to the production or distribution of dairy produce;
Scientific, economic or technical research
Training of persons
Dissemination of scientific, economic or technical information and advice
Publication of scientific, enconomic or technical reports, periodicals, books and papers.

That is where the research is going and that is certainly where it is necessary. Over the last few years we have seen a considerable improvement in fundamental matters such as breeding and feeding, improved use of fertilisers, the handling and housing of cattle and matters such as that. This followed on directly from the advice that was given in the Industries Assistance Commission report. I refer to page 72 of that report which states:
It was suggested that one way in which dairy farm productivity could be further improved was through dairy herd improvement.
It went on to list the following eight items:
genetic improvement;
herd recording; and
herd management;
herd health programs;
veterinary diagnostic laboratory services; and
mastitis monitoring;
centralised testing stations; and
co-ordinated information operations.

These measures have been largely achieved. The Australian Dairy Farmers Federation has concentrated on trying to ensure that the important items of dairy production have been followed through. It is interesting to note, from a table which I obtained from the Library, the extent to which milk production in Australia has improved during the period 1974-75 to 1979-80. I seek leave to incorporate the table in Hansard.
Leave granted.
