TALK.START.PARA: —The table shows that in New South Wales the average milk production per cow in 1974-75 was 2,476 litres. By 1979-80 this average was 2,906 litres, which is an increase of 430 litres. In Western Australia it rose from 2,702 litres in 1974-75 to 3,049 litres in 1979-80, an increase of 347 litres. The Australian average increase over the same period was 147 litres but I am somewhat disappointed to find that the Tasmanian average increase was only 83 litres. This is disappointing because while the Tasmanian average yield per cow is of course higher than the other States-as it should be because of better soil, better climate and so on-we have had quite an extensive government program on herd improvement. Nevertheless, we seem to have made less progress than about half the number of States when we look at the national average and we have made considerably less progress than the better States. There is certainly room for more improvement.

SPEECH.PARA: More inducements should be offered, I believe, to the producers by the processors. I will cite a couple of alternatives that have been suggested recently, some of which are in operation in other places. I refer to such things as subsidies on fertiliser beyond certain basic levels; heavily subsidised herd recording programs for total herds; insemination subsidies for world class size; subsidies for pregnancy testing; and added extension service advice on pastures, forage pest control and other production related items. There are a whole host of items where I think the processors can assist the producers in further increasing their cows' production. The returns in 1976, at the time I first became a senator, were about $100 per cow, per year. In Tasmania for this year this is now being discussed on the basis of approximately $400 per cow, per year. I hope that within two years, on the present anticipations, this will be about $500 per year. Primarily, to achieve this, not only will we need better production but also we will need more consolidation and rationalisation in the processing sector.

According to a newspaper article the chairman of the dairying division of the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association, John Charleston, said recently that there were 13 receival points in Tasmania which between them were not handling as much as was being handled by one point in Victoria. I receive regular reports that in various places up to four milk tankers are on one road, and of course there are excessive costs in duplicated managerial and production staff. I am told generally that approximately 40 cents a kilogram is being lost in duplication costs, and I believe that dairy farmers, both in Tasmania and Australia-wide, are now at the point where they expect to receive more of that money than they have in the past. The producer has done his part by arriving at his current level of efficiency and will now expect to be paid the amount available through the elimination of duplicated costs. It is generally considered that the over-capacity in the manufacturing sector of the industry is of the order of 35 per cent to 40 per cent, or possibly more. The cost of maintaining this over-capacity is borne directly by the producer, certainly not by the processor.

I wish to make two final points. Firstly, I concur with Senator Walsh's statement that, from the dairy farmers' point of view, they would be wise to support moves for market forces trading in Australian dairy products. It may be desirable right now for us to be importing some products from New Zealand while at the same time selling products in other areas at better prices. That would assist in maximising the returns to the farmers. The present arrangements will be at the expense of these same farmers. The second point I wish to make relates to the present discussions on closer economic relations with New Zealand. For the benefit of the governments on both sides of the Tasman, I make the point that those relations do not involve the abolition or dismemberment of the Australian dairy industry. The Australian dairy industry will certainly not be the sacrificial calf in achieving closer economic relations. For both economic and strategic reasons, Australia must retain a viable industry. We are down to about the level of reasonable viability now, and I think it is only sensible that we should try to restrain further contraction until we have time to level out. The Australian industry needs a little more shaking down but it does not need shaking out in any way.

There are three points on which the discussions with New Zealand should be based as far as the dairy industry is concerned, and a similar situation would apply to the horticultural industries. Firstly, all trade should be stripped of any advantages, benefits, bonuses, and so on. Secondly, where we are dealing together on overseas export markets, we should work on a co-operative basis and program these markets between the two countries. Thirdly, where we are dealing with each other, agreements should be arranged between producers on both sides of the Tasman. Such agreements have worked quite satisfactorily for certain other products, notably through the Australian Pea and Bean Industry Panel. I again commend the dairy farmers for what they have done in becoming as efficient as they have become in the last five years, and I ask the processor section to consider what the farmers have done and try to do likewise. To achieve that purpose we should be able to use the funds of the account we are currently discussing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills currently being debated are the Dried Vine Fruits Stabilization Legislation Repeal Bill 1981, the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Bill 1981, the Apple and Pear Stabilization Amendment Bill 1981, and the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill 1981. These Bills are associated with price guarantees for apple and pear exports. The Opposition will not oppose any of the Bills. The package of Bills associated with apple and pear pricing changes the basis of industry support from stabilisation to underwriting. Those are jargonistic or fog words which have little meaning to people who are not fully acquainted with the industry, and perhaps little precise meaning even to those who are acquainted with the industry. The change embodied in fact is quite important. Previously governments have guaranteed supplementary subsidy assistance for apple and pear exports to European markets, within some market price parameters. Those prices were set arbitrarily and frequently, I suppose, with a significant political input. That system has been phased out and the price support system now to operate will be in the form of a guaranteed or underwritten price related to actual market prices, effectively as determined by market prices on a three-year moving average. Although extreme fluctuations in prices from one year to another cannot occur, as the prices trend is either upwards or downwards, the underwritten price will follow that trend, albeit with a smoothed and time-lagged effect.

SPEECH.PARA: This system follows the precedent which was first established by Labor when in government, in regard to the changes to the wheat industry guaranteed price formula in 1974. The apple and pear legislation is more efficient on two grounds: Firstly, because the underwriting provision will apply to exports to all markets. The previous provisions applied only to European markets and therefore effectively discriminated against exports to non-European markets and actually discouraged the industry from seeking to develop markets in the non-European area-the area, incidentally, where the prospect for growth is probably greatest. They are also more efficient in that they are price related instead of being determined completely arbitrarily. We commend those changes and note that they are in line with the recommendations made by the Industries Assistance Commission in a report released, I think, last year.

The Dried Vine Fruits Stabilization Legislation Repeal Bill, as the name implies, repeals the existing Act under which, whenever actual export market returns were more than $10 per tonne above or below the set price-that set price again being more or less an arbitrary price-growers either contributed to or received payments from the stabilisation fund. The history of that stabilisation fund over recent decades is that the Government has frequently been obliged or required to contribute public money to the fund to enable payments to be made. In other words, grower contributions have not equalled grower withdrawals from the fund. But in recent years that longer term trend has been reversed and in fact payments into the fund were based on the 1978 crop. It is confidently expected that payments based on the 1979 and 1980 crops would also be made into the fund if the existing legislation were to continue.

The Government has decided to repeal the legislation both in order to avoid contributions being made from the 1979 and 1980 crops and also to expedite the distribution back to growers of contributions made in 1978. I suppose one could say that by terminating the present and long-standing marketing arrangements at this time the industry is getting out of that arrangement while it is in front, but I guess few people would probably begrudge that privilege to dried fruit growers. It is forecast in the Minister's second reading speech that the old stabilisation arrangements will be replaced by underwriting arrangements at some time in the near future. The Opposition hopes and trusts that the underwriting arrangements ultimately chosen for this industry will in principle be similar to those incorporated in respect of apples and pears and, more recently, for other agricultural industries; that is, whatever the underwritten figure is, it will be related to actual market returns, probably with a smoothed and time-lagged effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Dried Vine Fruits Stabilization Legislation Repeal Bill, the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Bill, the Apple and Pear Stabilization Amendment Bill and the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill. I wish to express concern about some aspects of the underwriting aspects of the legislation. This concern is shared by, I should say, the majority of growers from my State of Tasmania because apples and pears are a particularly important part of the economy of the State. In this joint debate I wish to concentrate on the three Bills which are connected with apples and pears. As most honourable senators would be aware Tasmania, in the past, has produced approximately 67 per cent of apples which are exported to at-risk markets. Therefore, the problem of the at-risk market raises all the consequences of local overproduction and underproduction and other countries' apple supplies to Europe, including the United Kingdom. But Tasmania is also plagued by problems of uncertainties in such things as shipping schedules, limited frequencies of services, some extra cost of packing materials, interruptions on the wharves and the degree of industrial disputation. All these problems to the local grower are compounded when one recognises that one is dealing essentially with a perishable product.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills essentially reflect the Government's acceptance of the major recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission report No. 239 on apples and pears dated 28 March 1980. Basically what we are looking at today is a phased withdrawal of the stabilisation provisions. In the case of apples they will be phased out over a period, whereas the $2.20 a box subsidy for exports to the United Kingdom and to Europe will be phased down so that in 1982 it will be $1.65, in 1983 it will be $1.10, and in 1984 it will be 55c. The total amount of money involved in the new arrangements will also be reduced. In 1981 it will be $2.475m and it will decline to $825,000 in 1984. The stabilisation arrangements in regard to pears will be reduced after one season. These arrangements will create problems because the stabilisation scheme which has operated since 1971 has produced a stabilising effect on the incomes of all apple and pear producers. In fact, it was stated in the IAC report that if the stabilisation arrangements had been withdrawn in toto this would have reflected approximately a $6,500 decline in the net income of producers in Tasmania and lesser reductions in the net incomes of the mainland producers.

I think it is significant that prices in 1980 were the highest ever and that in that year a significant new trend emerged and many Tasmanian apples were not exported to the mainland. Some growers diverted their support from the Tasmanian Apple and Pear Marketing Authority and were selling at the very much higher prices which were prevailing on the mainland. Price variations were significant. Last year some varieties sold at approximately $9 a case. So the combination of production drops due to storm damage and higher prices prevailing on the mainland caused at least one ship from Tasmania to be cancelled.

The Tasmanian Apple and Pear Marketing Authority, I believe, has done great work. The last few years have been fairly difficult for that organisation. I believe it is trying to do a job and at least is starting to get on top of some of the problems. I am rather concerned that this movement from a stabilisation scheme to an underwriting scheme will destroy some of the confidence of the Tasmanian producers at a time when I believe confidence is sorely needed . Some of the initiatives by TAMA, for example included the securing of a contract for the export of 100,000 cartons of apples in 1980 to Taiwan, with a contract extending into 1981 and 1982. In the past I have been fairly critical about the advertising and about some of the administration of the Apple and Pear Corporation. I trust that with its new chairman it will show more a vigorous and business-like approach, especially to advertising.

Therefore, I am quite happy with two of the Bills but it is the underwriting Bill which causes me some concern. The point I wish to make is that the underwriting provisions provide assistance on the basis of 95 per cent of an average of four seasons; so one takes the last four seasons and applies that average to the fifth season and takes 95 per cent of it to determine the underwriting amount. But herein lies the rub; the underwriting provisions do not allow for inflation. Unfortunately, inflationary levels are still unacceptably high and because this formula does not make provision for inflation the producers-essentially, Tasmanian producers, who form the bulk of exporters-are the ones who will suffer most. I appeal to the Minister at the table, the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), to see whether perhaps this debate could be adjourned and continued at a later date so that he could recommend that this percentage be increased to 110 per cent, 115 per cent or, preferably 120 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on. Cut out the grandstanding.

—No, this is a sincere belief and requirement of the Tasmanian producers because they will suffer. They need a higher rate of compensation than is presently provided because so many of these producers have had very difficult periods. They can see some light ahead but these Bills have changed that. The IAC report came at a most inopportune time for the industry. I will quote from some of the submissions made to the IAC. For example, the Tasmanian Department of Agriculture stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Stabilisation and Supplementary Assistance should be continued.

I will now explain how the stabilisation scheme worked. There was a maximum Commonwealth assistance to $2.20 a box where exports at-risk were sold at a loss and further supplementary assistance was available on a dollar-for-dollar basis from State and Federal Governments to a maximum of $2.20 a box. This gave a maximum assistance of $4.40 a box. The Department also recommended a modified form of fruit growing reconstruction scheme to be introduced to complement the stabilisation scheme. This statement came from the Tasmanian Department of Agriculture directed by a Labor Party Minister so naturally we believed that statement was made with the support of the Tasmanian Government. The large Tasmanian company, Cascade Brewery Company Ltd, submitted that:
Assistance should be provided to the apple industry in some markets to maintain production at an effective level.
We can also look at the statements of others who made submissions. The Australian Apple and Pear Growers Association stated:
The Export Stabilisation Scheme should be maintained for an indeterminate period.
The Australian Apple and Pear Shippers' Association submitted:
The Stabilisation Scheme should be continued indefinitely.
The Australian Apple and Pear Corporation submitted:
The Stabilisation Scheme should be continued indefinitely and not be considered a temporary arrangement during a period of adjustment.

On the other hand we have the academic approach exemplified in the IAC report which opinion, naturally, has gone along with many of the conclusions of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. The Bureau submitted:
There is little justification for the continuation of the present Stabilisation Scheme, and the scheme is no longer appropriate for the problems of the industry.

As with these theoretical expositions, no consideration is taken of the effect on people's lives and on particular localities. Although there has been a tremendous drop in the number of people employed and engaged in orcharding in Tasmania, nevertheless the industry represents a significant contribution within the fragile Tasmanan economy.

Another problem Tasmanians have to put up with is, for example, the tremendous increase in the freight rate. For example, from 15 June 1979 to 20 January 1980, the sea freight rate from Tasmania to the mainland increased by 33 1/3 per cent. These are from figures provided by both the Australian National Line and the Union Steamship Company of New Zealand Ltd. There is an expectation of further bunkering charge in the immediate future to compensate for fuel price increases. When we make comparisons we note that the net freight increase, so far as the industry is concerned, is about 60c a carton over the period 15 June 1979 to 20 January 1980 on the Hobart to Sydney route trip. We compared this with a mainland road freight cost increase, over the same period and over a comparable distance, which was only 10c per carton.

The Tasmanian growers have also had problems because the transporting of fruit in bins rather than cartons has virtually collapsed as a result of freight rates becoming just too prohibitive. This was the result of a situation in which the freight forwarders were only allowed to carry a drastically reduced number of bins in a container which thus increased the cost per bin to an unacceptably high rate. Despite all our problems present production is increasing marginally. I do not think that the Tasmanian situation has been recognised sufficiently by many of the people on the mainland pushing for this new scheme rather than for a continuation of the stabilisation scheme. They fail to recognise that Tasmania is a significant producer. I seek leave to table two documents which I have submitted to the Minister at the Table and to the Opposition Whip. I believe the first document shows that the significance of Tasmania as a producer of apples is at risk. The second table is from the IAC report showing the distribution of production by regions in Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —When honourable senators read the tables in Hansard tomorrow, they will note that, if there is no export market or incentive for Tasmanians to export to overseas countries-Tasmanian producers need confidence at this point-many of the local supplies will be sent to the mainland. Consequently, this will affect the prices received by mainland producers because the total Australian domestic market is not all that large. Tasmanian producers would also like to see an amendment to the freight equalisation scheme to enable Tasmanian export apples to qualify for the freight rebate when sent overseas from a mainland port.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that, in adopting the major recommendations of the IAC report, the Government is essentially seeking ways, in many cases, of saving money rather than of helping an industry in dire need of stability at this time. The old stabilisation scheme applied to each variety of fruit. It is recognised that some varieties have better yielding characteristics than others. Under the underwriting scheme we make no distinction as to variety and refer only to apples in total. As I mentioned, an average as taken over the last four years free on board returns for export of apples provided the basis on which we determined a 95 per cent underwriting in the fifth year. Under this scheme, if a variety of fruit has a very bad year, it is not recognised under the new arrangements of the underwriting scheme whereas it was recognised under the stabilisation scheme. I believe that this change will work to the detriment of some of our Tasmanian producers. I reiterate that I believe that 95 per cent is far too low and does not recognise inflationary factors. Again, I ask that this aspect be considered most sincerely because it will be a thorn in the side of our producers, especially those from Tasmania. I believe our State Government has been showing some initiative to help local producers. A significant initiative is the payment of the salary of the Chairman of the Tasmanian Apple and Pear Marketing Authority.

It is a fact that growers are losing a degree of confidence in the export market. Unfortunately the export market has tended to perform badly because of the enormous competition, especially in markets in Europe and the United Kingdom. One of the problems in the past has been that Tasmanian producers have not been selling on terms as favourable as those offered by producers and authorities in South Africa and New Zealand. For example, whereas Tasmanian fruit in the past has been sold on consignment and at a firm price, overseas producers have been providing Europeans with much more favourable terms. The Tasmanian Government set aside $20m by way of guarantee to enable the Authority to borrow money so that our products could be sold on terms similar to those offered by South Africa and New Zealand. However, it is important that growers have this confidence to export good fruit in order to support the new underwriting scheme. I am rather concerned that there was not greater consultation with the industry, especially the Tasmanian industry. I am concerned at the 95 per cent underwriting. I trust that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) will take into consideration my request, although it is made at this very late stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Bill 1981, the Apple and Pear Stabilization Amendment Bill 1981 and the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill 1981. It is my intention to confine my remarks to only one of those Bills; that is, the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill. I want to refer briefly to the Corporation's functions, which are set out in the Corporation's fifth annual report. It cites section 6 of the original Act, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The functions of the Corporation are-
(a) to promote the export from Australia of apples and pears;
(b) to control the export from Australia of apples;
(c) to control the export from Australia of pears;
(d) to promote trade and commerce in apples and pears among the States, between States and Territories and within the Territories;
(e) to improve the production and encourage the consumption of apples and pears in the Territories; and
(f) such other functions in connection with apples and pears as are provided by the regulations.

It is not my intention, having listened to Senator Watson, to engage in the real politics of apples. I remember that in my youth Tasmania was known as the country of ABC-apples, beer and cupids. I found that out when I visited Tasmania some 40 years ago, not to pick apples but to do another job. The reason I entered this debate was to put a case on behalf of the South Australian apple and pear growers whose representatives visited Parliament House before we rose for the Christmas recess. They expressed some concern that both South Australia and Queensland had no representation on the Corporation.

If we look at the overview which is set out in the latest annual report of the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation we will see the production figures for each State. In 1978 New South Wales produced 3,071,000 boxes, with production rising to 5,685,000 boxes in 1979. New South Wales has one representative on the Corporation. Victoria produced 3,458,000 boxes in 1978, with production increasing slightly in 1979 to 3,527,000 boxes. Victoria has three representatives-not all grower representatives-on the Corporation. Queensland and South Australia have no representatives on the Corporation. In 1978 Queensland produced 1,387,000 boxes of apples, increasing to two million in 1979. South Australia produced 940,000 boxes in 1978, increasing to 1,237,000 in 1979. Western Australia produced 1,861,000 boxes in 1978, increasing to 2,465,000 boxes in 1979. Western Australia has two representatives on the Corporation. Tasmania produced 3,489,000 boxes in 1978, increasing to 3,915,000 in 1979. Whilst it can be truly said that both my State of South Australia and Queensland do not export very many apples, it is the feeling of the grower associations in both of those States that they ought to have some representation on the Corporation.

The purpose of the visit of the Apple and Pear Growers Association of South Australia to Canberra late in 1980 was to make representations in that regard. Mr Kerin, who is the Opposition's spokesman on primary industry, and I were able to speak to these people. We then took the matter up with our party's committee on primary industry. I wish to read part of a letter which I received from Mr Lockier, who is the Manager of the South Australian Association. He states, in part:

A meeting of the President of the Australian Apple and Pear Growers Association and the Chief Executive Officer with the Minister of Primary Industry on 28th January last resulted in the Minister's agreement to increase the grower representation on the Corporation from four to six providing all states agree.

Our members are concerned that 'State representation' cannot be written into the legislation which does mean that a future Minister could appoint two persons from one State at the expense of another State.

We have notified the Australian Apple and Pear Growers Association that we agree to the Minister's offer to increase members representing growers on the Corporation from four to six provided not more than one such member is appointed from each State.

A meeting of the Opposition's committee concerned with primary industry agreed to support the South Australian growers' case for a representative from each State. I hope that when the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) makes the new appointments, which I guess will not be until the end of this year, he will give due consideration to the representation of both Queensland and South Australia on the Corporation, in view of the figures I have cited. Whilst some of the representatives of the Corporation are not directly representative of the growers, they are representatives of the particular States. I will just repeat the figures: At present Victoria has three representatives on the Corporation; Tasmania has two; Western Australia has two; and New South Wales has one. Queensland and South Australia have no representative. It would make for great harmony in the industry if all States had a voice on the Corporation, despite the fact that South Australia and Queensland have very low production figures.

In years gone by, I was a poultry farmer and I went through the traumas of the chaos that results when people trade outside an orderly marketing system. If all States are represented on a corporation or a board they are able to put a point of view. If any problems arise they can put that point of view and probably chop off any problem at its source. After checking with the powers that be last year I was able to ascertain that there have been some changes to the Corporation since the printing of this report. I notice that Mr Boynton is the new Chairman of the Corporation, that Western Australia has a new representative by the name of Mr Gubler and that the Victorian representative, Mr Chandler, replaces Mr English. So, as Senator Watson pointed out, there is new blood on the Corporation. I have received no complaints about the Corporation, although Senator Watson seems to have received some. He said that he hoped that the expertise of the new Chairman would help the industry, particularly in marketing. Without being critical of the past Chairman, I join the honourable senator in saying that I have put a point of view on behalf of the South Australian growers organisation. As I have said I hope, when the time comes for new appointments to the Board, that the Minister will take cognizance of the suggestion to increase grower representation from four to six and that both Queensland and South Australia will be represented.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—As Senator Walsh, who led for the Opposition in this debate has said, we are supporting all the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — in reply-The Senate has been considering a group of Bills which have to do with apples, pears, dried vine fruits and stabilisation schemes. I understand that the Bills, which are supported from all sides of the House, aim at balancing the need for income security with a continuing capacity within the industries to be able to adjust to changing circumstances. When I was outside the chamber listening to the broadcast of the contribution by Senator Watson I was aware of two things. First of all, I was aware of the matters to which he adverted-some of the points which he brought up-and also of his specific request. The three Bills-the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Bill, the Apple and Pear Stabilization Amendment Bill and the Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill-bring together a group of propositions which were the result of a very lengthy process of negotiation. They went to the Industries Assistance Commission; there was government consideration; there was public discussion; and there were submissions from interested parties. Of course, that is not necessarily the end of the matter. Senator Watson has now put a series of points which deal with an alternative way in which the matters might still be resolved.
—Just altering one figure.

—I have tried to make some inquiries. It is not possible at this stage to delay the passage of the Bills. I will seek, if I may, to put the propositions into the Government system and I invite the honourable senator to talk with me later to see whether we can take his suggestion further. The level of 95 per cent on average returns which did emerge was a result of considerable compromise and argument. I ask in the interests of comity that we take that course.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLaren made a point to which I think we need to respond and he has made this point before, I seem to recall, in relation to membership of the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation of States which are not represented at the present time. I noted that his State colleague Senator Young indicated his agreement with the point that Senator McLaren was raising. Senator McLaren is correct in saying that the number of grower members on the Board is limited to four. Queensland and South Australia have objected but they have little or no chance of being represented. The honourable senator did set out the membership which indicated that neither Queensland nor South Australia had representatives as such. Following recent representations from the Australian Apple and Pear growers Association seeking added grower representation, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) has undertaken to re-examine the membership with a view to increasing the number of grower members from four to six, but on the basis that the selection would remain with the Minister and would not necessarily be on a State basis. The increased membership from four to six possibly may give a capacity to respond in ways which the honourable senator has indicated would be desirable. Having made those remarks, I thank honourable members for their general support of these measures and I commend the Bills to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate on the motion for the adoption of the Address-in-Reply was interrupted I was dealing with that aspect of the Governor-General's Speech in which His Excellency said:

SPEECH.PARA: The foreign policy priorities of my Government are clear. It is very conscious of the need for a strong and united Western stance towards the Soviet Union and to this end it will work to maintain its already strong ties with its traditional allies, and in particular with the United States. It should be clearly understood that it will do so out of an appreciation of Australia's needs and interests and for no other reason.

I had drawn attention to the fact that the maintenance of strong ties has particular relevance for the Northern Territory. Firstly, it meant allowing Pine Gap, that is, the Joint Defence Space Research Facility base, to continue to operate despite the fact that it is controlled by the American Central Intelligence Agency, that the Australian Government is not aware of its real purpose, that private information from Pine Gap is given to commercial organisations in the United States and that its activities would make it a prime target in the event of nuclear war. The second comment I made was that the maintenance of strong ties means that by offering Darwin as a stopover base for American B52 aircraft it would become a prime target. I had said that there were three reasons why we of the Opposition oppose the use of Darwin as a B52 stopover. Firstly, the fact that it would make Darwin a prime target. That would mean that the two major centres in the Northern Territory would become major targets. Secondly, I had spoken about the possibility of an accident if nuclear weapons were carried on these aircraft. And thirdly, I had spoken about the fact that the decision of the Government ties us into American policy and removes our independence. I had reached the point of commencing to talk about the use of Darwin as a B52 stopover base tying us into American policy. I now deal with that aspect.

Australia wants to be an ally of the United States. There is no doubt about that. We have firm commitments in that area. But we do not want to be a satellite, a colony or a minion of the United States. We are allies and there is no doubt that our policies will usually, but not necessarily, be the same. We must have our own positive, independent policies. I am convinced that if we had them and expressed them clearly we would get more respect from the world, particularly the United States.
What ties Australia and the United States together? Basically it is the ANZUS treaty. Let me deal quickly with the ANZUS treaty without going into it too deeply. Article IV states:

Each Party recognises that an armed attack in the Pacific area on any of the Parties would be dangerous to its own peace and safety and declares that it would act to meet the common danger in accordance with its constitutional process.
Article IV states:

For the purpose of Article IV, an armed attack on any of the Parties is deemed to include an armed attack on the metropolitan Territory of any of the Parties, or on the island Territories under its jurisdiction in the Pacific or on its armed forces, public vessels or aircraft in the Pacific.

Basically the ANZUS treaty is a watered down version of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. Honourable senators will recall the NATO phrase which goes something like 'an attack against one, shall be considered as an attack against all'. I do not know whether that is the exact wording of the phrase, but that is the sentiment of it. The ANZUS treaty does not do that. The United States Congress specifically left out this provision because it did not want it included. Some of the older honourable senators in this place might recall what a former leader of the Australian Labor Party, Arthur Calwell, had to say in the House of Representatives in a debate on the ratification of the ANZUS Treaty. He said:
He said:
There is an obligation on USA and all the other participants in the European Treaty, NATO, to go to each others aid. The only guarantee that it is given in the Pacific Treaty-
That is the ANZUS Treaty-
is that the nations will consult in common . . .
Honourable senators will recall that I read that phrase from Article IV. He went on:
There is no real obligation in the Pacific Treaty on anybody and on some grounds it would be better to have no treaty at all.

I wish to sum up briefly what ANZUS is. It is clear that the United States is not required to come to Australia's assistance in the case of an attack. I am not suggesting that it would not come to our aid. It came in 1914 or a little thereafter. It came in the 1939-45 conflict. It did not come to our assistance at the beginning but it did a little later. The treaty does not require the United States to come to our aid and that is the important thing. Unfortunately, ANZUS means what the United States says it means when and where it feels like it. Most people realise that the very meaning of ANZUS has been the subject of debate in the United States. The people of the United States are still not sure what it means. I suggest that there is no advantage in having bombers refuelled in Australia and that there are many disadvantages.

We have to recall that the use of nuclear weapons is now thinkable. It was not some time ago, but it is now. People are considering the use of nuclear weapons. Certainly we do not want to have one of the key foreign bases that would be knocked out in the initial skirmishing. I suggest that before any decision is taken, the people of Darwin be consulted. A straw poll taken within the last fortnight shows 67 per cent of people are against B52 bombers landing at Darwin and only 20 per cent in favour of B52s landing in Darwin. In other words, the position here is similar to the Iceland situation. Some honourable senators may have noticed that the Iceland situation was dealt with on the 60 Minutes program recently--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an excellent program.

—It is an excellent program, as my colleague says. It covered the objections that Iceland has to the B52s landing in its territory. Other sites in Australia have been suggested by me and by others. If we must have these aircraft landing in Australia let us use some of the other sites and make sure that these sites are away from the major centres. The United States does not put its bases close to towns or cities. We should not put these bases in Australia close to towns and cities and we should not allow the United States to do so. The problem, of course, is that it is very difficult to get factual information either from the United States or from the present Australian Government about what is really happening. The people of the Northern Territory have been bombarded by the Murdoch Press in the Northern Territory News. It favours the landing of the B52s. I would like to draw attention to an editorial of 5 March 1981 under the heading: 'Bullying bear nonsense'. The editorial stated:

SPEECH.PARA: For once the Soviet Ambassador in Australia has departed from his usually low profile to warn that Darwin could become a future nuclear target if the Federal Government decides to allow American B-52 bombers to refuel here.
How the Labor Party's prophets of doom must be chortling 'we told you so'.
This was just what the Lefties have been delighted to forecast. The Ambassador, Dr Nikolai Soudarikov, has made their day.

One can only ask what goes on in the mind of an editor who writes that sort of drivel. What strange values would a man have to attribute that sort of value to fellow Australians? We tend to judge others on our own standards. I shudder to think what the standards of that editor must be to make those sorts of statements. What an example of journalistic objectivity! We are not prophets of doom. I am one of those to whom he is referring. We are concerned politicians. We are concerned about Darwin and its surrounds. We are concerned about Darwin's people. We are concerned about our families. I am concerned about my family. I suggest that we would be delinquent in our duty if we did not draw attention to the danger inherent in B52s landing in Australia. Further on in the editorial, there is the comment:
But let's get this threat into perspective.

It is then suggested that the United States has the same nuclear resources as the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. It has not, but that is not important. It is clear that the United States is concerned that Russia has an advantage. That does not give me any joy despite what the editor of the News may think. The article continues:
The effect of one nuclear bomb being exploded in anger would be to plunge the world into such total catastrophe that the significance of Darwin's aircraft landing strip would be paltry indeed.
Darwin would be far less important, in a military sense, than hundreds of other United States installations in dozens of countries.
Such an event would be rather like cracking a peanut with a sledgehammer. Use of a nuclear warhead to knock out Darwin airport borders on the ludicrous.

It is obvious that the editor is not listening to what has been said or using the Press releases which have been sent to his newspaper, which is not unusual for him. Certainly, I have never suggested that a nuclear bomb would be used. It would not be necessary and it would not be appropriate. It would be more appropriate to use a conventional weapon. But the point I make is that if the B52s were not landing here, there would be no need to knock out the airstrip. The editor continues:
Darwin doesn't figure in the Kremlin's sight any more than countless more strategic targets.

I suggest that that is the only reasonable comment in the whole editorial. That last comment, 'Darwin doesn't figure in the Kremlin's sights any more than countless more strategic targets', defeats the logic of the whole of the rest of the article. If it does not figure, good, let us keep it that way. It will figure if the B52s land. We have been warned, not for the first time. Let us heed the warning. Let the people be consulted before we have any suggestion that B52s might land in Darwin.
The next paragraph of the Governor-General's Speech states:
Beyond this my Government will concentrate its efforts heavily within the region, broadly defined, and on the Commonwealth of Nations.

I was very pleased to hear this statement. I hope that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) will follow the excellent advice given 2 weeks ago by the late Senator Knight, who was an expert on foreign affairs, when he made an excellent speech in this place. Speaking of Indonesia, he said:

I do not think we should act at any time at the expense of our national integrity of our international standing. If we are going to avoid that, or even the suggestion of it, in my view we will have to be rather more forceful and direct in our relationships with Indonesia.

He then went on to indicate that we have not been forceful and direct with Indonesia in the past. He gave the example of Timor. I support the stand made by Senator Knight on that occasion. Firstly, in relation to the refugee situation what will we do? Will we allow into Australia or regard as normal applicants those 2,500 people who want to enter Australia? In this regard, I was particularly pleased today to receive an answer to a question I put to Senator Durack on 27 November on the matter of East Timorese getting into Australia. It states:

Nominations in favour of over 1,000 East Timorese have so far been received under the special humanitarian program arrangements announced on 7 October 1980 and processing of these in the State offices of my Department is going forward rapidly. It is expected that the majority of the nominations will be acceptable under the relaxed criteria established in respect to this program.
Further on in his reply, Senator Durack said:
Two families approved under this program have already arrived in Australia and I expect that movement will shortly gain momentum and continue well into 1981.

I commend the Government for that change in attitude because certainly, at one stage, very little attempt was being made to have people regarded as refugees and brought into Australia. Perhaps some of the comments made from this side of the chamber had some little effect on the Government and its change of attitude.

What will we do in this area in respect of communication? We know that Fretilin has begun broadcasting again. Will we continue to hound that group of Australians in the Northern Territory who try to maintain family links with the people in East Timor and which provides the only vocal contact with the group in East Timor? Will we continue to harass them, maintain that they do not have a licence to operate and make it difficult for them to establish that vital contact? Will we continue to forbid the telecommunications centre in Darwin from receiving and relaying messages? Let us trust not. Let us hope that the words of the Governor-General will not have that effect. What will we do in relation to the arms sales to Indonesia? Will we be like the United States of America and Britain and others and supply patrol boats, planes and arms to Indonesia? Will we provide equipment to allow Indonesia to blockade East Timor and starve and rape its people into subjugation? Will we do that or will we be concerned about the East Timorese people. I hope that the Government will not follow the call of the former Ambassador to Indonesia, Mr Critchley, when he said we should forget the past and look to the future like some sort of Victorian melodrama. It is not too late to save some of our former allies. It is not too late to take a stand. I commend the late Senator Knight's approach on this matter to the Government.
On the economic aspect, the Governor-General had this to say in his Speech:

There is, however, a continued need for the firm application of consistent policies to reduce inflation and to allow our national resources to be employed in areas where the highest economic return can be obtained.

I ask the question: The highest economic return to whom? Let us take one example, that of Ranger and the sale by the Government of the people's equity in Ranger. Honourable senators will recall Sir Edward Cohen of the Electrolytic Zinc Co. of Australia Ltd urging the Government to stay with Ranger until production. What did the Government do? It set up Energy Resources of Australia and in undignified haste allowed its friend in big business to make a 'killing'. There was no attempt to maximise the Australian people's involvement. In fact, to the contrary, every attempt was made to make sure that the small people of the Northern Territory and of Australia were not able to become involved in this venture.
The ERA prospectus states:
Under the Government agreement Peko and EZ enjoyed a more favourable position than the Commonwealth and the A.A.E.C. . . .

It is referring, of course, to the price ERA paid to Peko Mines Ltd and EZ for their interests in the project. What is the financial structure of ERA? Peko has 125 million shares or 30.8 per cent of the total shares. EZ has 125 million shares or 30.8 per cent of the total shares. Overseas participants have 98.4 million shares or 24 per cent of the total shares. The public has 57.9 million shares or 14 per cent of the total shares. Of the 94 million shares not issued, four million shares were held in reserve for another overseas power utility. This parcel has already been sold to a Swedish concern which is prepared to buy uranium from ERA. It paid $1.40, a 40 cent premium on the initial issue. However, that was considerably below the market value at the time which was $1.90.

ERA escaped criticism of the price charged because 'B' shares cannot be listed on Australian exchanges until 30 June 1984. In other words, although this transaction was within the letter of the law it was an unfortunate-and one might even say underhand-practice to give foreign buyers a considerable advantage over the locals. When ERA became listed on Australian stock exchanges the price hit $3 in a matter of hours. Its marked capital was over $1,000m. Overnight it leapt to stardom as Australia's eighth largest company. The Commonwealth-and therefore the Australian people-did not get a fair return for its investment. The $1 issue was a means whereby EZ and Peko offloaded the Commonwealth. That it was grossly undervalued can be seen by the frantic trading immediately shares became listed. When shares opened a report of the time stated:
On the first 2 days 2.9 million shares were traded-there is the suggestion the people in the know or friends of the stockbrokers snapped up the shares at the $1 issuing price.
They knew full well they were undervalued:

They were not serious investors in the sense of a long term commitment to the development of a Resource but only interested in quick profits. Many small Australian Investors missed out and some only got a small part of the number they requested.

In other words, the Australian Government allowed millions of dollars of the Australian people's money to slip through its fingers. EZ and Peko were given a bargain. The Australian people paid the price. They paid the price in that small investors were not able to participate as fully as they wished to and they were denied the money which would have come from the sale and which, of course, would have eased the tax burden to some degree.

I would like to mention now the involvement of the Federal Government in Northern Airlines and the unfortunate situation we find ourselves in at the moment. Northern Airlines has been a disaster from the beginning. It is quite clear, as I have said in this place before, that the Northern Territory Government chose the wrong airline, blocked the people's company-Trans-Australia Airlines-from getting in and gave the contract to East West Airlines Ltd. The chosen airline selected the wrong aircraft. The aircraft, the Metroliner, which was selected needed longer runways than were provided on most of the Aboriginal communities. Our colleague, Senator Cavanagh, has already drawn attention to the fact that money which should have been allocated to the welfare of Aboriginal people was used to extend the runways when that should not have been necessary. We know that the Metroliner had propellers which were slung too low and on the strips in the outback they were damaged in many cases. At $10,000 a throw per propeller it soon became an expensive operation. The Metroliner was not suitable for carrying out work in the Northern Territory and the schedules which were arranged were not those which would have been economically advantageous to the company.

At this stage I do not want to dwell on the Northern Territory Government involvement but rather the Commonwealth Government involvement. The problem Northern Airlines faced was that a surveillance contract would be allowed only if Nomads were used. Perhaps this could be reasonable except that the company had to wait up to 12 months for the delivery of the Nomads. In other words, the Government Aircraft Factories was not able to supply the Nomads and the Government would not allow the company to use any other aircraft. Northern Airlines was paid only for the section that was covered. In other words, it was behind the eight ball from the word go. The Chairman of East-West Airlines, Mr John Riley, lashed the Northern Territory Government. He said:
I personally advised the Chief Minister in late November the company was not receiving the amount of government support and business which was part of the original regional airline concept.

This lack of support and business was resulting in losses which Northern could not afford to sustain. The content of that last comment and the quotation come from the Northern Territory News of 20 January this year.

John Riley complained about the fact that there was a lack of government support. He gave as an example the fact that the Minister for Health and Minister for Mines and Energy, Mr Tuxworth, spent $99,996-nearly $100,000-on air charter in one year. Often the aircharter he took ran parallel with schedules run by Northern Airlines in its flights from Tennant Creek. In other words, a good section of that $100,000 should have gone to Northern Airlines to help support the company. It is fair to say that Mr Tuxworth never supported the airline. In a telex message to his leader, Mr Everingham, on 18 April 1980, he said:
There are many complicating factors in the proposed introduction of East West Airlines-
That is, into the aerial medical service-

that are starting to worry me. I believe it has the potential to be a political time bomb, and for this reason I would like to keep the aerial medical operation separate as I do not believe we should allow this part of the Health Department to become involved in what might become a fiasco.

That is a fair indication that Mr Tuxworth had a better appreciation of the political situation than did his leader. In the same telex Mr Tuxworth pointed out that the Northern Territory aerial medical service contract was being given to Northern Airlines at a tender price of $170,000 above the quote made by TAA. Of course, as we all know TAA had been efficiently carrying out the work for 20 years. Its quote was $170,000 below the quote from Northern Airlines, which was accepted. There was ample warning in the Press, from the people involved and from commentators that Northern Airlines was going bad, yet the Northern Territory Government did nothing about it. The winding down of the company meant the closure of the Alice Springs aircraft servicing facilities. That meant a loss to the Territory of a great store of expertise and an excellent training facility for the young people of the Northern Territory.

Suggestion has been made in some quarters that the Northern Territory Government indulged in complicity with Ansett Airlines of Australia so that it could step in when Northern Airlines finally tumbled. I have no evidence one way or the other but certainly this comment was made in the Press and was broadcast by radio stations. We do know that discussions were held with Murdoch over the chancellorship of the university just prior to the Northern Airlines blowup. It is unfortunate that investor confidence has been seriously shaken by this state of affairs in the Northern Territory. My concern is with the Federal Government involvement and the part that the Federal Government played in the downfall of Northern Airlines.
I commend Mr Dondas, the Minister for Transport in the Northern Territory, for a statement which I chanced upon only today. The Northern Territory News of the sixth of this month stated:
The Government will consult with NT communities before deciding which airline will succeed failed Northern Airlines for regional operations.
Transport Minister, Mr Dondas, said today he would discuss details of Ansett and TAA proposals with people at Katherine, Tennant Creek and Nhulunbuy and the outlying centres.
''It is important to find reactions to the two main proposals from the people who will be using the services'', he said.

I commend him fully for going to the people and asking them what they want. There has been reluctance on the part of the Northern Territory Government, as there is on the part of the Federal Government, to go to the people and find out what they want. I commend Mr Dondas for this action.

The last section in the Governor-General's Speech I want to deal with briefly is the section headed 'Caring for People'. The Speech stated that concern 'is evident in the commitment to improve aboriginal health standards'. I commend this intention although I remind the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) that the road to hell is paved with good intentions. Certainly there is need for concern. There has been a drop in concern since the Labor Government was in power. There is no doubt about that. The Minister, who is a doctor, should know the relationship-and I am sure he does-between health and hygiene. At present the hygiene standards of a good many of the Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory are to be deplored.

In a question I addressed to the Minister last week, I referred to a statement by one of the elders at Ngurrkurr that his community was 'the biggest rubbish dump' in the Northern Territory. It is not enough simply to provide finance. It is not enough for the Minister simply to say. 'We have made money available to the Northern Territory Government.' It is obvious that it is necessary for the Minister to arrange the spending of that money to be checked by his officials. Councils have insufficient money for municipal services. It is no good saying that the Northern Territory has the total responsibility because in 1967 the Federal Government received a clear mandate to accept responsibility. The Minister must have the courage to face the Premiers and the Chief Minister on this matter. It is too important a matter to be left to the simple expedient of pleasing political brothers. I maintain that the Governor-General's words are meaningless, that they are empty rhetoric, unless they are followed by firm and decisive action on the part of this Government. I trust that we will see that firm and decisive action.

Before I quoted from that article I was referring to the New South Wales Senate campaign. I wish to make some remarks about the work of Senator-elect Bruce Childs, who is the Assistant Secretary of the Labor Party in New South Wales and who will become a member of the Senate after 30 June. I believe he produced what was the best how-to-vote card of any party in any State. He decided that in New South Wales the Labor Party's how-to-vote card would have the precise dimensions of the ballot paper, that it would be in full colour and that it would use a green border of the same colour as the House of Representatives ballot paper. Many members of our party were critical of this decision. They thought it would cause confusion among the voters and would increase the informal vote. But after looking at the statistics I believe that his decision in fact reduced the informal vote.

There was a straight distribution of preferences by the Labor Party in New South Wales. We did not distribute our preferences on an ideological basis as we did in 1975 and 1977. The voting procedure, which had to be followed, was printed on the how-to-vote card in eight languages. Again, I believe that this led to a lower informal vote throughout the State. There was a near 100 per cent distribution of the Labor Party how-to-vote cards in the letter boxes and roadside mail boxes throughout New South Wales. I believe that this also significantly reduced the informal vote, which in New South Wales was 9.38 per cent in comparison with the 9.7 per cent national figure and the 11.2 per cent figure for Victoria. I think those figures emphasise what I have been saying. We achieved this result in New South Wales even though it had the largest number of candidates of any State.

The Labor scrutineers reported that unlike the elections of 1974 and 1975, it was the Government that was losing the majority of votes in the strong Labor seats. It was the Government that was losing the most as a percentage within the smaller total. I should mention here that the concerted campaign that was run in such electorates as Sydney and Grayndler has certainly brought about a vast improvement. The Labor Party has won many thousands of votes since the events of 1974. In New South Wales we and our scrutineers were determined that the events of 1974 would not be repeated. We believed in 1974 that Peter Westerway in New South Wales and Senator Colston, as he is now, would both have a reasonable chance of being elected had the party been able to achieve the proper scrutineering that we are now able to achieve. We estimate that we spoke personally to over 2,000 scrutineers. One elector in the electorate of Warringah, Mrs Audrey Isobel Parrett, received an official form from the Commonwealth-an application for a postal vote. This form was completely filled in. It showed her address, occupation, subdivision and electorate, but also stated why she was applying for a postal vote.

It was typical of the tactics that were used by the Liberal Party in New South Wales to obtain a majority of the postal votes in the last election campaign.

I have a whole file of these complaints here but I will give the details of only another one. Again the ballot paper that arrived was filled out completely for Mr David Marshall Lyndon James, of 3 Bolwarra Road, Elanora. The grounds on which he was seeking a postal ballot paper were that he could not vote on the day because of his membership of a religious order and because of his religious beliefs. Again, the how-to-vote card was authorised by the northern metropolitan region of the Liberal Party. The envelope that it came in was from the Willoughby Office of the Liberal Party and, of course, the person did not seek that postal ballot paper. Mr James is a councillor of the Warringah Shire Council in Sydney and he won his position on that council, standing as an endorsed Australian Labor Party candidate. Yet he received an application for a postal ballot paper from the Liberal Party which also outlined how he should vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are getting desperate when they do that, Senator.

—They were getting very desperate but it did not work. As said, I believe that even the posting of the form was a breach of the Commonwealth Electoral Act and I will do something about that matter at a later stage. In the New South Wales campaign that I referred to, all of our Federal and State members of parliament, union officials, and members of the party rank and file were rostered as scrutineers. They responded magnificently, especially in the rural areas of New South Wales. We had Labor Party scrutineers in all of the 43 Commonwealth electoral offices. The result was that at a crucial stage of the vote, when the corrected figures were put in, because of the work of the scrutineers, we found that the total vote of Mr Nile, who was the recipient of the donkey vote in New South Wales and the Australian Democrat candidate, Mr McLean, who was second on the ballot paper, dropped by 29,000. Both Senator Puplick, the Government candidate and I, the Labor Party candidate, gained votes and at that stage the Government's lead over the Democrats was only 22,500 votes which points out how the scrutineering was absolutely crucial to the result and how the Labor Party gained victory as a result of it. However, it does raise the question: Why is this necessary? Honourable senators may ask: Why have I dwelt for so long in this speech on the mechanical aspects of the campaign and of the polling? Senate voting and the Senate voting system is antiquated. The system, as we know it at the moment, is a lottery. The Government lost ground in New South Wales. If the Government looks at the position that its candidates drew on the ballot paper on an Australia-wide basis, it would realise why it lost. It might say that it was bad luck but it is the luck of the system. The system needs a complete overhaul. I consider any system, under which one in every 10 voters in New South Wales casts an informal vote to be a joke.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make some brief remarks about the situation in Western Australia because of my experience in the recount of the Senate result in 1975 in New South Wales. I believe that if the votes in Western Australia were counted again, either in Perth or Canberra, we would get a different result. I say that because in the recount that occurred in 1975 in New South Wales, the Labor Party won on the first count by 854 votes-that is, by 19 votes per Federal electorate throughout the State. That is very similar to the result that just elected the last candidate in Western Australia. About the same number of votes per electorate were involved. But when there was a second count I finished up winning by a total of 2,016 votes. People said that that was not a great difference-854 to 2,016 out of a total of three million votes-but what I would like to point out is that the total formal vote in that count dropped by over 10,000. On those results, I consider the system at the moment to be a disgrace. In the recount in New South Wales, the big losers were the party that gained the majority of the votes-that is the Government-and the party that received the donkey vote. If there were a recount in Western Australia the same situation would apply. The party that received the donkey vote and the party that received the majority of votes, in this case, the Government, would be the big losers. I believe that on a recount the final result would be completely different. I am not saying that there would be a different senator; I am not saying that the third Liberal candidate would not win if the votes were recounted. I am saying that there is a possibility that that might not occur. I am 100 per cent certain that there would be a different result in terms of how many votes that candidate would win or lose by.

Because of all these factors, I think one of the crucial things facing this Parliament in the next three years will be the issue of electoral reform. I think it is absolutely imperative that we have a new look at the Commonwealth Electoral Act. This has been promised by successive governments and by successive Ministers. When Senator Withers was the Minister in charge of the Act he promised a complete overhaul and an updating of the Act. It is not my intention to speak at length on electoral reform, but I do think it is crucial that we look at whether candidates for the Senate should pay deposits and the method of nomination. There is no doubt that in New South Wales we had joke candidates. We had disc jockeys and rock groups standing for the Senate for one reason only-not to be elected but to seek publicity for their own activities. I think there has to be a strong look by this Senate at what constitutes a genuine candidate. We have to look very carefully at whether we should make it essential that people number every square on the ballot paper. We ought to look at whether we have an optional preferential system as we have for the Legislative Council in New South Wales. We ought to look at whether we need a list system such as operates in a number of countries in Western Europe at the moment. It is not my intention tonight to go into all the different changes that I believe should occur to the Commonwealth Electoral Act; I will save them for a later date.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise again to take part in this debate on the Address-in-Reply and in doing so I want to make a few remarks regarding the amendment which was moved by my leader, Senator Button, on 5 March 1981. As honourable senators are aware, I spoke earlier and at length. I propose tonight not to speak at length but I would like to refresh the memories of Government senators in particular regarding the wording of the amendment moved by my colleague. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following words be added to the Address-in-Reply:
'But the Senate is of the opinion that the Government-
(1) Has failed to adequately respond to:
(a) record unemployment;
(b) a high and worsening level of inflation;
(c) reduced and falling family living standards; and
(d) the highest taxation burden in the nation's history.
(2) Allows unsatisfactory administration of foreign investment guidelines which permit an uncritical and open-door policy to the takeover of Australian industry and resources to continue; and

(3) Makes no long-term provision for assistance to manufacturing industry and farming industries, which are likely to be severely disadvantaged as a result of successive exchange rate revaluations and substantially increased imports in the context of resources development'.

That is almost a blanket motion pointing up the weaknesses of the Government's approach to the Address-in-Reply. I know that we have heard some very pretty speeches from Government senators who were very proud of what they were doing, but we on this side of the chamber find much which we want to criticise. I think the most adequate way in which to do that is to illustrate our points of criticism.

When this country went to the polls in the last general election in 1980, nothing was said by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), or by any of his Ministers that they were considering whether to impose a new tax, that they were considering whether to impose further restrictions on the national health service, that they proposed to take away the unemployment benefit from those under the age of 18 years, or that they proposed to appoint a razor gang to further pare back the Public Service and make it less competent than it ought to be. I could go on for the next 25 minutes detailing the sorts of things that were hidden when the election campaign was going through its various phases.

I refer first of all to a factual case in relation to Medibank. I received today a letter from a lady who pointed out that if Medibank or the national medical service was no longer going to cover the cost of acupuncture, she would suffer. Before I quote from her letter I point out that for ethical reasons I do not propose to name the doctors but they are named in this document if any one wants to have a look at it. Her letter states:

. . . I always seem to write when I have a problem and this time this is a formal request to voice my protest in parliament . . . Sounds grim . . . anyway what it is-is: I have just heard that acupuncture is going to be stopped as a medical benefit. True or not I don't really know . . . As you know I suffer (suffered) terribly from asthma. Records in the Cairns Base Hospital will show it was completely out of control and I can't for the life of me remember the name of the doctor I had in Cairns, but if need be I can-and he would vouch for this. He recommended we sell everything and get out of Cairns or it would be curtains! At this stage I was on everything imaginable and even was having 'aminophylin' drips in hospital. Well, 18 months ago we went to Rockhampton where the climate was drier and again spent most of the time in hospital. Records there will show this. The chest specialist I had was Dr . . . Here in Rocky I met up with a lady doctor, Dr . . . of . . . Street. She practised acupuncture and said the asthma could be controlled with acupuncture. Well, when you are desperate you try anything. She also said that it was the heat and muggy weather and that we should go to a cooler climate. So . . . off again--
They are now living at Landsborough, not very far north of Brisbane, just off the main highway in the hills. The letter continues:

three months ago we came to the Maleny range, near Caloundra and I go to another doctor who does acupunture every month on me and for the first time in my life I can honestly say the asthma is controlled or I even feel that it is cured. I do not take any medication now-and I had been on cortisone.

I suppose most honourable senators would be aware that cortisone is one of the more powerful drugs. It does cure some people but it has many side effects which can be quite dangerous. The letter continues:
I have had no asthma attack since January last year-
That is, over 12 months-
I have been having the acupuncture since January last year. My doctor here is Dr . . . ., Caloundra.

. . . could you please present this as a case history for the use of acupuncture. It costs about $29.00 for about 2 hours once per month and I get 100 per cent back through Medibank. You are free to use my name, address, doctors, anything you wish.

That is a plea from the heart from a lady whom I have known for the last 17 or 18 years and who has suffered very badly with asthma. Of course Mr Fraser has now made this announcement. I would like to see him stick to the portfolios which he has allocated to himself. I think I saw today in a newsletter that someone suggested that very thing-that Mr Fraser not poke his nose into industrial affairs and that there be some change of portfolios because people have been big noting themselves about the Qantas Airways Ltd dispute in particular; but I will have more to say about that in a moment. I am glad to see that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) is in the chamber.

Another major complaint I have-I think it is well covered by the references in the amendment to the Address-in-Reply-concerns the inability of some Ministers to come to grips with their portfolios, the inability of other Ministers to be able to send out an acknowledgment to the effect that they have received a complaint and the inability of some Ministers to even deal with the complaint at all. I do not like sending urgent telegrams because they are more costly than the ordinary form of telegram, but sometimes there is no alternative. I addressed the telegram to the Minister in these words:
Am advised that three Bairnsdale Aboriginal organisations, the medical service, the housing co op and the alcohol rehabilitation service--
which is about to operate-
have been raided by CIB and books and cheque accounts confiscated.
Am informed by local NAC rep that this was done at the instigation of the local National Country Party member. . .
I then asked the Minister:

I have a little more detail of which to inform honourable senators. I received another letter today from the chairman of the Community Council, Mr Aia at Sai Bai Island, which is within two or three miles of the Papuan coast. In that letter, Mr Aia told me that, on about 26 September last year, he wrote to the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs mentioning the Community Development Employment Project and asking whether money could be provided. Sai Bai is a coral or sand cay. Once within recent memory, Sai Bai Island was covered by a very high tide, probably of subterranean influence caused by an earthquake or by some other subterranean upheaval. But, nevertheless, the people there were given a grant some four or five years prior to that tide to build a rock sea wall to keep the water off the island. That work ran out about a year ago and there is no alternative employment in that area at the moment.

A school teacher is paid below award rates. Labourers are paid below award rates just to look after the community. There are many people who do not have jobs at all. That is another matter on which the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and successive Ministers have dithered. The then Minister and the Department backed off when Mr Justice Matthews made an order, I think in May two years ago, to the effect that award wages were to be paid to the communities. That great leader of democracy, Mr Porter, now retired-thank heavens-flew down here. The husband of the senator-elect who will appear in this chamber either after next Thursday or after 30 June said that the Queensland Government could not afford the $7m the Sai Bai people wanted. The Aborigines of these communities were deprived for many months more of an adequate wage structure. Finally, a decision was arrived at which was not the rate for the job which is expected by everybody, including politicians. There are some politicians who complain that they do not get the correct rate for the job. Nevertheless these people have to paddle their own canoe-if one chooses to use that slang phrase-yet, as far back as last September, the chairman of this community wrote to the Minister. He got a reply from his private secretary about two weeks. There has been a wall of silence ever since. In desperation, he wrote to me about a week ago. I received the letter today. The letter is now in the pipeline to the new Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume. I have a number of other matters to which I wish to refer but I, like Senator Sibraa, think these are matters which ought to be transferred to a more major debate. But I wish to refer to three other departments. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has been a type of lone ranger system for a long time. I do not blame the staff of that Department; I think they are highly competent people who are handicapped by an unimaginative Minister, a minister who is afraid to take any initiatives and who looks at the Numerical Multifactor Assessment System as the answer to everybody's prayer and who counts migrants, particularly those from the Asian areas, as numbers on a chart.

Prior to Christmas 1980, a young Chinese couple from Hong Kong who had been in Australia studying for a year or so came to my office hoping that they could stay in Australia. It took them from then until the end of February for the Minister to decide that they could not stay in Australia. It is not much use sending urgent telegrams. One might as well send a carrier pigeon with a note in its beak, not tied to its leg because I do not think some ministers would know how to undo an ordinary knot. I suggest that we might tape messages to the pigeon's beak. But when that young fellow came into my office there was a job for him at Rockhampton, a provincial city in Queensland, where a handicapped children's home had been trying for many months to get a teacher with his qualifications. But the Minister had gone on holidays immediately after the election and did not come back until just before Parliament was called to meet, or was unable to read his correspondence or had handed the matter over to the bureaucracy with all sorts of threats as to what it should do about it. After he went back to Hong Kong, I got a letter from the Minister referring to my urgent letter of a date, many weeks previously, and stating that they could not stay here. That is what we do. I know that there are problems in relation to the second-class degrees which are given in the Philippines universities but nevertheless if somebody is able to--

—You are not referring to the Prime Minister are you? There are areas in which people get their own expertise and they are more than capable.
