TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's Speech and the amendment moved thereto by Senator Button. The outstanding attribute of the Governor-General's Speech, apart from its pomposity, is the startling contrast between the rhetoric and the reality of the Fraser Government. In the third paragraph of the Governor-General's Speech it is claimed, on behalf of the Government, that the Government's policies are designed to work for the well being of all Australians. That statement is from a government whose two proudest boasts are that it is alone amongst the Western nations, including Europe and North America, in abolishing all forms of taxation on wealth and capital transfer in a country which has two million people living in poverty and that it has consistently repudiated a resources rent tax which not only is more efficient in purely technical economic terms but also would ensure that the benefits of the impending mineral development would be more widely spread in the community. Later in the Governor-General's Speech we heard a mass of contradictions when it was said that the Government's policies:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . have been given coherence by an economic strategy which is designed to restore economic stability.
This strategy has already resulted in an encouraging pick-up in activity and employment and a marked strengthening in business investment.

This was asserted by the Governor-General on behalf of the Government. It is correct that over the last 18 months, for the first time since the mid-1970s, there has been a significant increase in the number of people in employment. In fact, there has been an increase of 180,000 employed persons in the last 18 months. The reasons for this have nothing to do with the economic strategy enunciated by the Fraser Government back in 1975 and 1976 and rhetorised about ever since. The reasons for the economic recovery in the last 18 months can indeed be found in the fact that the Fraser Government has substantially repudiated those economic policies. For example, the money supply growth in the previous two years has run well above the Government's planned targets. Real wages have increased in the last 12 months and this has shown up in higher consumer spending. Despite all the rhetoric to the contrary, government spending, which had been increasing slightly in the 1978 and 1979 Budgets, increased in real terms by 3 per cent in the 1980 Budget. To the degree that there has been an economic recovery in the last 18 months, it has happened not because the Fraser Government has adhered to its stated economic policies but because it has, to a substantial extent, repudiated them in practice, if not in rhetoric.

It is ironic, in view of the present controversy between the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the permanent head of his Department, that at the end of January at the Agricultural Outlook Conference John Stone should have delivered what was not only a highly political but also an intellectually dishonest speech. Reiterating high Tory dogma disguised as economic verity, he asserted, firstly, that inflation was caused by growth of the money supply; secondly, Budget deficits increased the money supply; and thirdly, rigid control of government expenditure has reduced the deficit in recent years. There were no qualifications, no exceptions and, of course, as always with John Stone, no possibility of error. In fact all three propositions are fallacious. Money supply growth can be a cause of inflation, but does not necessarily cause inflation. Budget deficits do not increase money supply if they are funded by domestic borrowing. Government expenditure in real terms has increased in each of the last three years, and by about 3 per cent in the current year. The deficit, it is true, has come down in that period, not because of rigid controls on government expenditure but because taxation has gone up.

Since that would be known to any second-year economics student who had a look at the Budget Papers, one can only assume that the Treasury Secretary had decided to massage the prejudices of his audience and to proselytise his own political ideology with the aid of economic fallacy. He, like the Government, boasted at length of the employment growth of the last 15 or 18 months, the cause of which he had no doubt, of course, was the economic policies of John Stone and of the Fraser Government. Heretics who had doubted the infallibility of John Stone and of the Fraser Government were for ever vanquished, he implied.

The basic trouble with those claims by both the Government and its Treasury Secretary is that the employment growth of which they both brag took place in a period of rising inflation. A fundamental tenet of earlier Stone and Government encyclicials was that rising employment and rising inflation were mutually exclusive. When that final point was drawn to John Stone's attention at the Agricultural Outlook Conference, he assured what he must have taken to be a very credulous audience that the reason that employment had grown in spite of the rising inflation of the last 18 months or two years was that it was known that inflation would turn downwards again, as indeed it had done in the last couple of quarters. So monetarism has now been amended yet again apparently. Monetarism and inflationary expectation theories of unemployment have been amended yet again. They always incorporated infinitely variable time lags. They now apparently have been amended so that the time lags can be positive as well as negative. Shortly afterwards in the Governor-General's Speech this was asserted:

There is, however, a continuing need for the firm application of consistent policies to reduce inflation and to allow our national resources to be employed in areas where the highest economic return can be obtained.

There would be little disagreement with that statement in itself. There would be a great deal of disagreement from anyone who has actually watched the Fraser Government's performance as to whether it has actually done that. When confronted with difficult political decisions about the structure of the economy, the Fraser Government has always done the opposite; it has always taken the soft political option. It was further asserted:

A primary objective of my Government will be to continue to fight against inflation. Inflation results in fewer jobs and lower living standards for everybody. Firm anti-inflationary fiscal and monetary policies are therefore essential to any lasting solution to the problems of unemployment, the achieving of higher growth and the more rapid raising of living standards, on a sustainable basis.

I refer to the facts that I mentioned earlier; that is, that far from such economic growth that has taken place in the last 18 months taking place in a period of falling inflation and falling inflationary expectation, the empirical fact is that it has taken place in a period of rising inflation and rising inflationary expectations, a phenomen which both John Stone and the Government consistently asserted, and continue to assert, could not happen. I do not suggest, of course, that inflation necessarily causes economic growth; just that the real world is much more complex than is acknowledged by pontifical zealots like the Treasury Secretary or realised by simplistic ideologues like the Prime Minister. The speech continued:
It will be an important policy objective to continue to restrain public expenditure so as to provide scope--
Wait for it-
for reducing the burden of taxation.

That talk of restrained public expenditure and reduced taxation comes from a government which currently presides over the highest levels of taxation and the highest levels of government expenditure, as a proportion of gross domestic product, that this country has ever known. I pass no judgment on whether it is a good or a bad thing to have those levels of taxation and government expenditure, but it is again an indisputable fact that that is the case. Far from restraining public expenditure and reducing taxation, the Government presides over the highest levels of both ever recorded; and it has the audacity to insult the intelligence of this Parliament and of the nation by putting such pap and drivel into a speech for the opening of parliament.

That situation is not likely to change. Last October-I think it was the first-six weeks after we had been presented with what government propagandists had assured us was the most responsible and the best considered Budget in history, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) made no fewer than 61 additional commitments either to increase government spending or to forgo government revenue-from the $500m Alice Springs to Darwin railway to the $2m car racing track for Canberra. I presume that, as Ronald Ziegler used to say, that particular promise will be inoperative, since it failed to save John Haslem. No less than $4 billion has been promised for airport development and expansion throughout the country; $90m for the Burdekin Dam; and $10m for retrospective waiving of tax assessments on imputed rentals in central Queensland. I instance also such ill-considered Country Party sops as a farm fuel storage tax rort under which expenditure on tanks in which to store fuel on farms will be immediately deductible for taxable income-a seemingly insignificant item which is tucked away among 61 promises but which, if it is effective to the extent of causing farmers to store an additional six months supply of fuels on farms, will cost government revenue about $75m. It is particularly ironic, in view of the reported statements of the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, at the National Country Party conference last week that the razor gang would be getting stuck into some of the fat in the farm sector or what more accurately could be described as some of the tax rip-offs which this Government continues to provide for the advantage of the high income groups and the outside investors in agriculture and to the disadvantage of those who are actually concerned about making a living from farming on a continuing basis. That particular bonus for inefficiency-that is, storing fuel on farms-is also somewhat hard to reconcile with Senator Carrick's boast two months later that Australia, in conformity with its obligations to the International Energy Agency, was supporting a stocks draw-down policy designed to minimise or prevent supply caused increases in world oil prices by drawing more heavily on accumulated stocks in net importing countries. That co-exists with the Government policy which allegedly is designed to encourage farmers to store more fuel on farms.

All of the 61 promises were either uncosted or dishonestly costed. I draw just two examples of the latter, of which the dishonesty has been subsequently acknowledged. One is the extension of the liquified petroleum gas subsidy said to cost between $9m and $11m and now admitted by the Government to cost $13m. Another is the allowance of a 20 per cent rate of depreciation on farm machinery which was said by the Government in the policy speech to cost $7m. It is now admitted in a letter that I received last week from the Treasurer to cost $20m-up from $7m to $20m! I could go on and on about the Governor-General's Speech, or more accurately the speech that the Governor-General delivered on behalf of the Government, but I will move on to a couple of other areas.

The Prime Minister's economic contradictions are matched by his military contradictions. Our Prime Minister, as those who have observed him over the years will be aware, has long indulged in military command fantasies. The most recent evidence of this has been the ludicrous security arrangements in Parliament House which he imposed after the Hilton Hotel bombing and whatever was responsible for that; his bellicose posturing toward the Russians and his endorsement of President Reagan's attempt to get a re-run of the Vietnam war in central America. Curiously this penchant to involve others in shooting wars to contain communism has never extended to involve himself. In 1951, with the Korean war raging, he thought it was much more important to depart for Oxford to pick up that third class degree. In the mid-1960s, while he was still well within military age, his contradition to stopping communism in Vietnam was restricted to using his power as the Minister for Defence to send thousands of Australian conscripts into the shooting war.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1980 parliamentary opening was the last which will be attended by Sir Garfield Barwick as Chief Justice. The great tragedy about Sir Garfield's retirement, like the death of Menzies, is that it came many years too late. If it had come 10 years earlier, for example, there may have been no emasculation of section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act as a result of a series of bizarre judgments by the High Court under Barwick's tutelage. Almost certainly, there would have been no infamous advisory opinion to Kerr in 1975 and there may not even have been any falsification of company records by the Chief Justice of the type we saw when he filled in that directoral resignation form dated 1974 but signed in April 1980-that bogus resignation form which falsified company records in order to conceal the activity of the then Chief Justice as a tax evader. Apologists for the late unlamented Chief Justice have stressed that most of his controversial judicial decisions can be ascribed to the alleged fact that he is a judicial literalist. He takes the letter of the law, it is said, and takes a narrow interpretation of it, or so these credulous people say. I remind those who have swallowed that line that the fiction of a caretaker government is entirely the work of the late Chief Justice. The Constitution says absolutely nothing about caretaker governments or anything remotely resembling them. Where was this great literalist who abides only by the written letter of the law when he concocted the fiction of a caretaker government in order to provide a rationale for dismissing the elected government and installing Malcolm Fraser in its place? I also remind those apologists of the Webster case when the facts were not in dispute. Former Senator Webster was a major shareholder and also had been the managing director of a company which had had numerous contracts with the Postmaster-General's Department. It was a private company of fewer than 25 persons. Section 44 of the Constitution states:
Any person who-

(v.) Has any direct or indirect pecuniary interest in any agreement with the Public Service of the Commonwealth otherwise than as a member and in common with the other members of an incorporated company consisting of more than 25 persons:
shall be incapable of being chosen of or sitting as a senator or a member of the House of Representatives.

One might have thought that a literalist jurist, confronted with that written Constitution and the undenied facts that the then Senator Webster was a member of a company consisting of fewer than 25 persons-a major shareholder and managing director of a company which had had contracts with the Postmaster-General's Department-would say clearly that Senator Webster was in breach of section 44 (v.) of the Constitution. This literalist jurist, however, as he always managed to do when he wanted to bring down a judgment that was less than compatible with the written law said, in his judgment, that no evidence had been produced that Senator Webster had used his position as a member of the Parliament to secure those contracts, which was true. The point, however, was that that had absolutely nothing to do with the charge. But on that basis, along with a couple of other spurious reasons, he found him eligible to sit. This literalist jurist has always managed to concoct fiction to rationalise the judgments which he had decided, frequently on political grounds, to bring down. He is no loss to the Bench.

TALK.START.PARA: —As you would be no loss to this Senate.
—The honourable senator will not be either; he will not be here. I will be here a lot longer than he will.

—It is right then, is it-what the Country Party supporters are telling us about Senator Carrick's going? I thank Senator Puplick for that interjection. —If he had observed the common decencies in 1974, in 1975, in 1980 and also in 1974 in the Webster case, he might be entitled to some respect whether he be on the bench or not. —Again, there is a need for this place to operate with a spirit of goodwill. So, there is this situation in which the basic element is a demand for a rigid application of the Standing Orders. I am prepared to go along with that if that is the wish of the Senate, but I want our proceedings to move along without interruption. The basic factor is that there must be a sense of decency and decorum. We should not rely completely on that which is allowed but on that which, among decent people, is acceptable. —I have finished with that item, Mr President. The last point I make concerns events that took place immediately before and subsequent to the election. SPEECH.PARA: The share market slump has proved that Labor's economic policies were wrong for Australia.

'What's happened in the stock markets of Australia yesterday and again today shows quite plainly how business, and the hundreds of thousands of Australian investors, view the prospects of a Labor Government', he said.
He went on to state:

Labor . . . would attack resource development, making it hard for business to get off the ground, and set up 'a spy unit' within the Foreign Investment Review Board, to pass on information about multinational companies within Australia to Australian and overseas trade unions.

The all ordinaries index bottomed on 15 October and 16 October at 661.4 and 661.5. It has been below that level for nearly all of the last five weeks. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak only briefly in this Address-in-Reply debate as it has been a long debate. It had not been my intention to enter the debate. Some incidents have occurred during the last few days in respect of which I thought it was necessary that one topic of the Government's policy be touched on. Under the guise of speaking to the amendment moved by the Opposition, certain comments have been made in this place in relation to the Government's manpower policy. Some of those comments I found a little disturbing. I found them all the more disturbing when I opened my newspaper in Brisbane on Saturday morning to read a story about a Vietnamese refugee who had been working as a barber and who had lost his job because of racist complaints made by a number of the customers of that barber shop to the owner of the barber shop. The Vietnamese migrant had a family, including four children, to support.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the public outcry in Brisbane, we read in our newspapers over the next couple of days that that refugee had been given a job by the same employer in another shop. But one concludes from the comments made and the news stories that one of the complaints made to the employer was that the Vietnamese in question had deprived an Australian of a job. All comment from those who worked in the same shopping centre and from the employer, the barber, indicated that the Vietnamese refugee was an excellent employee. The public outcry was such that the man now has a job. I think this is a warning of what could happen. All of us in Parliament, I think, have had comments made to them about the Government's policy in relation to refugees, specifically in relation to Indo-Chinese refugees. It would be easy to give in to the pressure that is exerted on all of us from time to time, particularly by those who choose to contrast the refugee policy with the immigration policy, to be critical of a refugee policy. In recent years we have taken a restricted number of migrants but we have continued to take them. However the Government has pursued as have Australian governments for many years its policy in relation to refugees.

I quote from the United Nations Convention relating to the Status of Refugees as amended by the Protocol. It gives a definition of a 'refugee' which has been the guidance of Australian governments for a long time now. The refugee is a person who:

owing to well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion, is outside the country of his nationality, and is unable or, owing to such fear, is unwilling to avail himself of the protection of that country; or who, not having a nationality and being outside the country of his former habitual residence, is unable or, owing to such fear, is unwilling to return to it.

I think we need to make a careful distinction between those who seek to migrate here and those who come here as refugees. Australia has always been very proud of the responsibility that it has accepted for contributing to the solution of refugee problems in many parts of the world. We have considered our policy in this area to be one of humanitarian assistance. Our assistance has taken two forms. It has taken the form of resettlement in Australia and contribution in the countries of first asylum. Australian governments have recognised that the preferable solution to refugee problems is repatriation where possible. However, they have also recognised that repatriation is not always a feasible solution to the problem.

In our region we are faced with an enormous problem in the form of the Indo-Chinese refugees. The most acute problem is that of the Vietnamese refugees who have been persecuted in their own country and whose own Government has made it very clear that they are not welcome to stay in their own country or that if they do stay they will suffer the consequences of having their property appropriated, of not being allowed to work and of being forcibly required to move to other parts of the country and undertake labour which is not reasonable. Most disturbing of all are the indications that within Vietnam much of that persecution of the domestic population has a racial basis. The persecution has not been confined to people in the south. Many people in the old North Vietnam have also been persecuted by the Vietnamese Government. That basis-a genuine fear of persecution-is the basis of any refugee policy.

We are all aware that there are those in Australia who would prefer not to see people of Indo-Chinese origin in Australia and who would prefer to see a certain racial mix preserved. Governments-Labor and Liberal-have rejected that attitude. I have had approaches to my office along those lines, as I am sure every honourable senator has. I have rejected them as unworthy. It would be unworthy of us as Australians to close the doors of our country and not to seek to extend humanitarian assistance to those who are without a home and who have the prospect of satisfactory settlement in this country. Our refugee policies have been supported by the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. For that support we ought to be very grateful because we face a difficult problem in the region which leads to a difficulty with our refugee problem. I would hope that no honourable senator, whether he be a Government or Opposition senator, would be tempted to make easy political capital under the heading of manpower policies of what they perceive to be a vocal minority of opinion in Australia in relation to refugees.

I reiterate to the Senate the basis of the Government's policy on refugees. Australia fully recognises its humanitarian commitment and responsibility to admit refugees for resettlement. The decision to accept refugees must always remain with the Government of Australia. Special assistance will often be needed to provide for the movement of refugees in designated situations or for their resettlement in Australia. It might not be in the interests of some refugees to settle in Australia. Their interests might be better served by resettlement elsewhere; that is, by support resettlement programs in other countries. It is estimated that in the world at present there are 13 million refugees. The number of refugees in our world is nearly equal to the total population of Australia.

I believe we have a first responsibility in our own region. However, Australia takes refugees from all over the world, not only from the Asian region but also notably from South America and Europe. We have assisted in the resettlement of refugees in other parts of the world in cases where it has not been appropriate for or the desire of those refugees to come to Australia. I believe we can be proud of our refugee policies as they have been conducted for many years. Approximately 10 per cent of the total of 3.5 million people who have come to this country in the last 30 years have been refugees. They have been successful and highly desirable settlers. I just regret that unworthy reflections were cast in this chamber on the motives of this Government in pursuing its refugees policies. The motives are no different from those of preceding governments in pursuing refugee policies in relation to displaced persons and persons throughout the world who are persecuted and without a home.

DEBATE.TITLE: BOUNTY (POLYESTER-COTTON YARN) AMENDMENT BILL 1981BOUNTY (NON-ADJUSTABLE WRENCHES) BILL 1981COAL EXCISE AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose any of these three Bills. The Coal Excise Amendment Bill is simply a machinery measure to extend from seven to 28 days the period for making returns with respect to coal production. It is part of a legislative scheme going back to 1949 to raise funds for both long service leave and research in the coal industry. The measure here in issue will simply facilitate the administrative operation of that scheme. The Bounty (Non-Adjustable Wrenches) Bill involves a matter on which Senator-elect Siddons might be able to muster rather more lyricism than I can manage on this occasion, as his Sidchrome operation appears to be, if not the sole operation, certainly one of the handful of operations that will in fact benefit from this largesse.
—Then he would be disqualified on the basis of pecuniary interest.

—Indeed; and his lyricism would no doubt have to be expressed in muted or qualified terms or outside this chamber, but lyricism, I have no doubt, it would nonetheless be. We ought to acknowledge that the spanner industry has been in trouble from import competition and that something like 400 jobs-industrially democratised jobs at that-are at risk. The Industries Assistance Commission has recommended that temporary assistance be provided until a fuller investigation, together with a report and a determination of appropriate longer term measures, can be conducted. The Bounty (Polyester-Cotton Yarn) Amendment Bill also involves temporary assistance to an industry which has been in real difficulties. Again, it is simply an interim measure while longer term arrangements are being worked out as part of the total textiles, clothing and footwear package. The Opposition supports that Bill, too.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not my purpose to embark on any kind of lengthy examination of the industrial policy generally which discussion of these Bills might be thought to stimulate and, indeed, to justify. I make the point that if manufacturing industries of this kind are to be assisted-assisted they must be in the present economic environment if anyone in manufacturing is to stay employed, whatever the longer term need may be for rational reconstruction-it is wholly desirable that, wherever possible, such assistance be given, as is the case here, by way of bounty rather than tariff protection. When the bounty mechanism is employed the economic cost is precisely known and easily measured, the burden of the assistance falls squarely and equitably on taxpayers generally rather than on consumers who might well be ill-equipped to bear it, and the inflationary impact of the assistance in question is obviously minimised. With those few remarks I think I have exhausted what I have to say on these measures. Once again I simply indicate-following the very extensive debate, I might add, of these matters in the other place-that the Opposition does not oppose, nor would it wish to hinder, the passage of these Bills in any way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly in support of these three Bills, the first a Bill to amend the Coal Excise Act 1949. As my colleague, Senator Evans, has explained, this is very much a machinery amendment to overcome a restrictive provision. The intention of the Bill is to increase from seven days to 28 days the period during which returns and entries can be made for home consumption, in relation to coal which is removed to enable research and long service leave collection payments to be made. So the amendment is proposed to overcome an administrative problem and to provide a more realistic interval in which these returns can be lodged.

SPEECH.PARA: The second Bill, the Bounty (Non-Adjustable Wrenches) Bill 1981 is designed to provide a bounty assistance of 11c on each bountiable wrench-this is important-which has a local content exceeding 50 per cent. The maximum payment in any one year is restricted to $620,000, so an upper limit applies. Under these circumstances, where essentially one manufacturer is involved, a bounty appears to be a reasonable sort of a way in which to provide protection. On the other hand, if there were a large number of operators and manufacturers, I believe protection would be more effective through quota or by tariff. In this case, where there is essentially one operator, namely Siddons Industries Ltd in Victoria, it is an appropriate means of protecting the local company and of providing protection to about 400 important jobs, essentially those of skilled workers who produce a good product. The purpose of this Bill is to enable local producers, essentially Siddons Industries, to get back to more normal capacity levels. It was pointed out that local producers have suffered from imports and it is hoped that the 11c bounty on each wrench will be sufficient to protect the local industry.

I have had a particular interest in the past in the third Bill, which is the Bounty (Polyester-Cotton Yarn) Amendment Bill 1981. The 1978 Act was designed to provide a bounty until 31 August 1981. This Bill before us tonight seeks to extend that period from 31 August to 31 December and, under this arrangement, $1.15 per kilogram bounty is paid on bountiable yarn. We realise that these industries are being subjected to an Industries Assistance Commission report, No. 240 of 30 April 1980. To some extent, this IAC report has been rejected by the Government. Some aspects of it have been picked up. It was recommended in that report that the present assistance arrangements be extended to 31 December 1981. The new arrangements will come into effect from 1 January 1982; it is just an interim arrangement.

I wish to speak on these new arrangements now. An upper limit of $200,000 applies during this interim period. In a full year it would be $600,000. I believe this is an appropriate occasion on which to raise a rather serious matter. The bounty for the future, that is from 1982, has been calculated on an incorrect assumption. This incorrect assumption is so dramatic as to wipe out much of the spinning operations within Australia. From 1 January 1982 it is envisaged that the duties on yarns will be reduced to minimum levels and bounties will be paid in lieu thereof. The bounty is to be paid as a fixed percentage of cost value added in Australia by yarn manufacturers; that is, the ex-factory value of bountiable yarn less the cost of materials used. With most cotton system spinning yarns which are produced by Australian industry, the bounty is to be in the area of 33 per cent of factory cost. This level of bounty will be completely inadequate for industry to compete with imports. Although I understand that there have been some discussions with officials from the Department of Industry and Commerce on the amount and the extent of this damage, I trust the Government at this point will, fairly quickly, see fit to correct this problem that has arisen; in other words, the inadequacy of the level of protection and the inaccuracy of the assumptions on which this has been based. In fact, I believe that the inaccuracy is so serious that I, and I think the majority of those involved in this sector of the industry, would regard it as a breach of faith on the Government's part, of its assistance to textiles which it declared just prior to the last Federal election.

I mention that the matter is so serious that the cotton system spinning sector of textiles could be sacrificed because of an incorrect assumption on the basis of the calculation used in formulating a decision. I believe that it is justly regarded that this sector of the industry is economically a very efficient sector of the textile industry of Australia; that is, the spinning sector. I trust that the departmental officers and also that the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) will come up with a formula which will fulfil our Government's electoral commitment in that area.

With that reservation and that very dark cloud on the future, I support this Bounty (Polyester-Cotton Yarn) Amendment Bill so as to extend for an interim period to 31 December 1981, the protection based on $1.15 per kilogram of bountiable yarn which is spun in registered premises for use in knitting and weaving of textiles here in Australia. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators on either side for their comments. Each senator has made his own contribution. I particularly noted Senator Watson's interesting remarks with regard to the cotton industry. It is well known in this place that he has a wide understanding, not only of matters of industry and protection, but also of the textile industry and particularly that of his own State. I acknowledge his expertise and informed opinion in this regard. I wish the Bills a speedy passage.

DEBATE.TITLE: ANSETT TRANSPORT INDUSTRIES LTD-ANNUAL FINANCIAL REPORT 1980

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly having regard to the fact that as I understand it the information was made available to the Department of Transport and therefore to government as a whole in the order of six months ago.
—They had a big printing bill. That was the problem.
—Senator Button has the call.

—Mr Deputy President, I have been greatly assisted by the interjections. I would like them to be recorded in Hansard. I shall summarise the situation as it is at this stage. It is nine months after the period to which these reports refer that the Parliament is receiving any detailed information and, as my colleagues have added, for six months that information has been in the hands of the Department of Transport which is responsible, in a sense, to see that these reports are presented in the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The second thing which follows from the presentation of these reports is that the report of Ansett Airlines of Australia particularly is totally outdated and, in terms of enabling honourable senators to detect the real financial position of that company, is quite meaningless. Thirdly, I think one can say that the impending actions by this Government, namely amendments to the Australian National Airlines Commission Act and an attempt to implement a new two-airline agreement for a period of 10 years, represent crucial decisions for the future of domestic aviation in Australia. More particularly, they represent crucial decisions for the potential passengers on Australian domestic airlines. Fourthly, Ansett, by presenting such a scanty document to the Parliament, has treated the Parliament with contempt. That, again, is a matter with which Senator Rae has been concerned in a general context in time gone by. Fifthly, the financial statement of Ansett could indicate a real profit, in our view, of at least 50 per cent higher than it has in fact admitted. I will return to that matter if the Senate is concerned with the precise details. The figure which is stated in the report as a real profit seems to be a little extraordinary if one looks at the net profit before tax, the company tax which is payable and the provision for taxation.

The discussion of these two annual reports must inevitably involve some reference to the most recent detailed observations on domestic aviation in Australia-truncated observations as they are. Those observations have been made in the report of the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares, chaired by Mr Warwick Holcroft, with Dr Harold Bell and Professor Warren Hogan. They are observations about which we have heard quite a bit in the Senate and about which we will hear quite a bit more in the next few days. I refer the Senate to some comments in the report and particularly to a comment on page 175 of Volume 1. Under the heading 'Administrative Control' the committee of inquiry states:

The inquiry has observed a number of features of the administration of air fare pricing which it believes should be altered as quickly as possible. By far the most important of these is the lack of public disclosure of financial and performance data by the airlines.

I remind the Senate that we are discussing the two reports of the airlines TAA and Ansett. The Committee says that the most important thing is the lack of public disclosure of financial and performance data by the airlines. Page 175 goes on:

The matter of public disclosure is, in the Inquiry's view, of overriding importance in the regulation of air fare pricing. A moment's reflection will recognise the irrationality of creating a protected joint monopoly, with a cost plus pricing system, and then affording the members of that joint monopoly secrecy in relation to costing and pricing.

The Inquiry points out when a company accepts a place in an industry into which competitors are precluded by law from entry and in which prices are set by law so as to recover costs, including profit, and in which longterm government policy prescribes that there shall remain only two firms, each capable of competing with the other, and by implication that they shall survive that competition, for each airline then to adopt the stance of being a firm in a highly competitive environment, jeopardised by the slightest disclosure, is plainly ridiculous. So too is the toleration that has been displayed over a long period by the regulatory authority of such a stance, apparently without asserting its right to be properly informed as surrogate for the public.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is pretty strong stuff.
—Yes, it is, Senator. The report goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: That the DOT as the regulatory authority has accepted this state of affairs is plainly shown by the numerous acknowledgements by the DOT of lack of data.

That is an extraordinary indictment. Perhaps somebody on the other side of the chamber could tell us it is incorrect but so far there has been very little evidence to that effect. That is an extraordinary indictment of a government, a government department and of a Minister who claims to be responsible for the administration of the two-airline system in this country and who is more particularly the author of the latest domestic airlines fares agreement.

In the last few days we have heard in this place some discussion about what public servants can and cannot do in pursuit of their roles as public servants when giving evidence to committees of this Parliament. We have heard some somewhat pompous statements by Ministers as to the extent of ministerial responsibility. The Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) said in this Parliament, that Ministers are responsible for policy. When we come to the Minister for Transport when the policy is an absolute shambles, who gets the blame? Not the Minister! The Holcroft inquiry gets the blame for that. Three distinguished members of an independent inquiry get the blame.

There is no question of ministerial responsibility when it comes to the Minister for Transport. The Minister for Defence is, as usual, full of hot air about the question of ministerial responsibility and is prepared to describe people, who express concern about the role of committees of this Parliament and the role of public servants who give evidence to those committees, in terms which are of the utmost clownishness and absurdity when one considers the real responsibilities involved. So the indictment of the Holcroft inquiry, if it is to be grappled with, is an extraordinarily powerful one of the Government. The response, of course, is to say that these people misread their terms of reference; they did not do their work properly and all these sorts of allegations which have been made by Ministers, particularly the Minister for Transport and the Minister for Primary Industry. If a person is under attack the best means of defence seems to be that of a skunk, that is, to emit some sort of smell which confuses everybody but which does not deal with the elements of the attack.

I think all honourable senators will detect that the inquiry not only is criticising the position of the airlines, and by implication Ansett Airlines, but also is highlighting the situation in which the Department of Transport as a regulatory authority has accepted a state of affairs which, according to the members of this inquiry, is against the public interest. I repeat: The Department of Transport has accepted, in the view of the inquiry, a state of affairs which is against the public interest. Again there is a lot of waffle about what the public interest means but it is seldom said in such clear and unequivocal terms that an action of a government department is against the public interest. The inquiry goes on to say that the Department plainly accepts this state of affairs by the lack of information it has. Ignorance is bliss for the Department of Transport when dealing with Ansett Airlines. That lack of information cries out for some response.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not just Ansett.

—Well, true, Senator, but I think that, if one reads the report, it can be seen clearly where the greatest indictment lies. I will come to that in a minute. We are discussing the reports of the two airlines but I take the honourable senator's point. The report is an indictment of the way in which this Department conducts itself and inevitably of a responsibility owed to this Parliament by the Minister for Transport. I reiterate these are reports to the Parliament. It is equally disturbing to read a further comment by the committee of a similar kind. I refer to page 14 of the first volume of the Report of the Independent Public Inquiry. Paragraph 1.53 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Although domestic aviation policy generally appears to be only vaguely defined it is clearly dominated by the two-airlines policy. This policy ensures the preservation of a duopolistic situation in which the key factors that might otherwise bear upon competition such as pricing policy, capacity, route frequencies, load factors et cetera are all circumscribed and are not subject to scrutiny by the Trade Practices Commission or the Prices Justification Tribunal. Moreover, to the extent that these non-competitive elements are not or cannot be effectively monitored by the Department of Transport, they are merely being rubber-stamped with the imprimatur of official approval.

I repeat: They are being rubber-stamped with the imprimatur of official approval. In a sense these are the issues which spring from this report. Some of the matters which are dealt with in these reports are some of the things which are being rubber-stamped by the department, according to the Holcroft committee. It goes on to say that any application for fare increases by the domestic airlines is being approved without question by the Minister. It is instructive that this comment appears after an official inquiry, because the fact is that fare increases are initiated principally by Ansett Airlines. That is the point I wish to come to and which relates to Senator Chipp's earlier interjection. That raises the question of the extent to which the principals of Ansett Transport Industries are able to exercise influence on this Government.

I said earlier that there are two actions pending which have immense importance for air travellers and for Australians generally. One is the amendment to the Australian National Airlines Commission Act. This amendment was introduced in the House of Representatives before Parliament was dissolved for the Federal election of October last year. It is now to be re-introduced. The real reason for its re-introduction and for amendment to the Act is to enable the imposition to be made on Trans-Australia Airlines, to which I will refer. That is to say TAA will be made to quadruple its profit objective. An accounting arrangement is to be introduced to force TAA to declare a profit which is really 400 per cent higher than it would otherwise declare. That will be done by having the airline's profit calculated on its assets rather than on capital invested. Honourable senators will be pleased to know that TAA has a mere $15m of government capital invested.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pleased?

—Senator Rae might not be pleased. I was using the word in a general sense, hoping that there was general good will here. Senator Rae is excused from that description by virtue of his particular interest and expertise. I repeat that most senators will be pleased to know that TAA has a mere $15m of government capital invested. Of course, it has been able to acquire many more millions of dollars in assets through efficiency and its attraction as an airline to the travelling public-something Senator Rae might find equally unpalatable, but it is nonetheless true. The real reason for imposing this profit burden on TAA is to force it to increase its fares substantially. Under the two-airline agreement, the fares charged by both airlines, TAA and Ansett, must be the same. That means that, because of TAA's need to increase its profits dramatically, Ansett would receive windfall profits running into millions of dollars.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the first element of this scheme. The second element is the attempt to implement a two-airline agreement for a period of 10 years. The policy decision on that matter has already been made. The implementation of the two-airline agreement for a period of 10 years would ensure that the situation of drastically increased air fares and windfall profits for Ansett would be guaranteed until at least 1991. Because the two-airline agreement has built into its terms a guarantee for five years from the notice of termination, the effective end of the agreement would be 1996. If something happened in the Parliament, an earlier termination date could be possible, but it would still be a long way away. In this situation Ansett Airlines seems to have called the shots. It gave the scantiest information to the Holcroft inquiry. Why? One can only suspect.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I interject for the purpose of gaining knowledge? Senator Button has stated that the policy decision on the two-airline agreement has been made, but it has not been ratified by the Parliament. Does he regard the two as synonymous?

—No, I do not. I said that the policy decision is quite clear. It seems to me to have been made. Ratification has not taken place, and that is a different thing. When I dealt with the question of notice of termination of the agreement, I hinted darkly--
—Through a glass darkly?

—Through a glass darkly, yes. I hinted darkly at a situation which I thought would have suggested to an alert person such as Senator Chipp that if something happened in this Parliament the termination of the agreement might be at some date other than 1996. That is my interpretation, and I think it would be the interpretation of an erudite gentleman such as Senator Chipp. As I have said, Ansett seems to have called the shots. It gave very little information to the Holcroft inquiry, and it has given precious little information to the Parliament in the report that has been tabled. Because the Holcroft inquiry was truncated, Ansett was not required to give evidence. It is common knowledge that at one stage Ansett sought the outright sale of TAA and that this proposal was shelved simply because the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) felt that the public would be outraged by such an act.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an open secret that Ansett has pressed for the quadrupling of TAA's profits by having TAA's earnings calculated on assets rather than capital invested. It is further an open secret that Ansett has been demanding ratification of a new 10-year two-airline agreement. It is an open, though disputed, secret-wide open, I should have thought-that the Minister for Transport has been totally compliant in these matters, and the Minister who represents him in the Senate has been totally confused. That is to say, we do not charge Senator Messner with compliance in this conspiracy but with the lesser venal sin of confusion, and that is amply documented at Question Time day after day. The Minister for Transport has shown no capacity for independent thought or action and a deplorable lack of oversight of the Department for which he is responsible.

Finally, honourable senators should take note of the lack of information given to them in the actual reports tabled in the Senate, particularly in the report of Ansett. They should bear in mind that Ansett will be the beneficiary under the terms of the two-airline agreement in the way in which I have stated we believe it will operate. Together with TAA, Ansett is given guarantees that would be the envy of many enterprises in this country. One would think, therefore, that a full obligation of this company is to declare in the fullest terms details of its operations. I take the point made in Senator Chipp's earlier interjection, but I am putting a case about the way the fare structure operates. Because the facts might be different at another time, the same obligation is on TAA to report to this Parliament, in the fullest possible terms, details of its operations. In fact, it is quite impossible, from a reading of the Ansett account, to make any meaningful comparison between Ansett and TAA, the two major airlines of this country. The scantiness of the first report takes liberties with the Parliament which should not be allowed.

Ansett's financial statements for the four sections of aviation operated by it-MacRobertson Miller Airline Services, Ansett Airlines of South Australia, Ansett Airlines of New South Wales, and Ansett Airlines of Australia-are a conglomeration of figures that do not disclose the true financial situation. The Ansett financial statements are unaudited, so in one sense they lack the credibility which even audited accounts of the smallest company would have. For example, Ansett discloses $28.3m before tax, and the tax provision is given as $20.3m. Those amounts lead us to believe that Ansett's net profit is far greater than is disclosed. There is also the write-back of depreciation or disposal of revalued aircraft. On a broad judgment, Ansett's profit after tax and extraordinary items would be $20m plus, due to non-allowable items for tax purposes such as writing back double depreciation on assets. The Ansett statement reinforces the need, and this was mentioned in the Holcroft report, for uniform detailed financial statements so that a meaningful comparison can be made between the two airlines and meaningful information can be made available to the Parliament and the Australian people on a matter which vitally affects them as very large consumers of these two important domestic airlines. The situation of the airlines concerns not only the Australian people but also their children who are of most slender years. Can I say slender years?

TALK.START.PARA: —Tender years.
—Thank you, tender years.
—In the Depression there were many slender years.

—That is true, and it could happen again during the time the domestic airlines agreement will probably run-potentially 15 years. On the other hand, TAA operates under the impediment of government policy restrictions such as superannuation payments in excess of Ansett's, different foreign loans incurring greater exchange losses, and so on. TAA also has many accounting treatments from past financial reports, and this tends to cloud the issue. TAA's performance is quite good, but not good enough in the circumstances surrounding the aviation industry.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary we say that the information provided by Ansett Airlines is inadequate for the purposes of assessing the true financial position of that company and of assessing its effect, having regard to the policy announcements which have been made on the fare structure of TAA, and that as an unaudited report it indicates contempt for the proper parliamentary process. The repeated assertions by the Opposition about the Government's failure to ensure proper, responsible examination of Ansett Airlines' accounts has been vindicated by the Holcroft inquiry. Indeed, the slender nature of the reports tabled by the airlines, having regard to the circumstances which I have referred to, is again an indication of contempt for the parliamentary process.

All one can say is that one wonders where the passing of the buck stops in relation to the reports of these two airlines. One wonders who accepts responsibility for these situations. We on this side of the House regard these reports, scanty as they may be, as most important documents in the life of the Parliament for the fact that they reveal not only very little to the public but also incompetence, lack of care and, possibly, a very grave situation of commercial favouritism by the Government which is disastrous in its implications for the development of industry in this country and potentially disastrous in the particular context of this industry. We are most concerned about this situation and hope that the Senate is prepared to see the situation as we see it and to take this matter further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very glad that the opportunity which was canvassed this afternoon has become a reality and that there is an early opportunity to have some debate in relation to the two delayed reports which were tabled this afternoon, namely, the reports of Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett Transport Industries Ltd in relation to their airline operations.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button, in speaking to this matter, has made certain comments in relation to the operation and accounts of Ansett Transport Industries. In particular, he made reference to the fact that its accounts are not audited. In case there is some misunderstanding in relation to that matter, the annual report of Ansett Transport Industries-namely, the forty-third annual report, 1980, which covers more than its airline operations-is in fact audited, and that report has been available to shareholders and to the public generally for some months now. The problem that arises is the problem of to what happens under the two-airline agreement, under government intervention in relation to airline operation in Australia, with the reports which deal solely with the operations of TAA and the operations of Ansett Transport Industries in relation to aviation activities. I am told-I have no reason to doubt this-that over recent years both Ansett and TAA have regularly been able to make the information available to government by late in the year, following the closing date of 30 June, for the period being reported upon. But for some reason which is not clear and which has never really been explained, notwithstanding attempts to raise it at Question Time, by way of debate on Bills, by way of debate on the adjournment and at various other times that I have raised this matter over the years, it takes so long for it to get through the process of the bureaucracy and of government before eventually it is tabled in the Parliament and is made available to members of parliament and to the public at large.

TALK.START.PARA: —The decisions are made by then.

—That is one of the problems. The information is important in relation to the decision-making processes not just of government but of all sorts of people. People involved in the tourist industry, in manufacturing, and in a wide cross-section are entitled to have this sort of information made available to them a long time before it is made available in the present circumstances. That is why I interjected gently during what Senator Button was saying by way of criticism of this situation. I have been criticising it for years. I do not criticise either of the airlines; I criticise a system which means that it takes so long between the preparation of the detail and the final publication. I wish somebody would just agree that this is an unacceptable situation which has to be changed. The processes of government somehow need to look at themselves before some people, including me, get to the stage of saying: 'If they will not do it, let us find out really why it happens and publicise why it happens and who is at fault'. Surely to goodness, after the number of times this matter has been raised, it is about time they pulled themselves into gear and got the reports out on time.

SPEECH.PARA: I have pointed out that Senator Button referred to the fact that ATI's aviation report did not have an auditor's certificate with it. I would not want it to be thought that ATI's general report was not audited. I just make that point. I notice that Senator Button is nodding his head, so there is no disagreement between us. As he made some comments about ATI's report, perhaps it is not inappropriate that I should have the opportunity, not by way of criticism but by way of statement of fact and of the problems we face in trying to delve into what on earth does happen in relation to the operation of the two-airline system in Australia, to make some comments in relation to the financial statements and report of Trans-Australia Airlines. I say it not by way of criticism of TAA but by way of criticism of the structure and of the system under which it operates.

One finds a great many problems when one tries to identify what really happens in relation to the operation of the airlines. Senator Button has referred to some of the comments about the alleged inadequacies of the information which is published by ATI. I do not pause to have any difference with him about that, but I would supplement what he said by pointing to some of the problems in relation to Trans-Australian Airlines, which I suggest are even greater than those which he may have identified in relation to ATI, yet they are of fundamental importance to matters such as those which were dealt with by the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares, the Holcroft committee. They are matters which are daily being dealt with at Question Time, and which are considered by government and others within the Parliament and externally, and they are matters relating to the question of what amounts to an air fares policy for Australia which is fair and which can produce an efficient operation.

Before one can come to conclusions about that, it is my suggestion that one needs to know what are the real figures, and from the accounts which are published there is no way one can work out what are the real figures. I can say that I have had the assistance of people who range from some of the leading stockbrokers in Australia to some of the leading company advisers, company takeover experts and a cross-section of others, to go through the published information in relation to the airlines. They stated qualification after qualification because the information is just simply not available. I should like to demonstrate some of those matters to the Senate tonight. I do not wish to debate the Holcroft committee's report but I should like to quote one item from it because I think it is relevant as a starting point. On page 124, in paragraph 7.113, of that report it was stated:

Other interest (that is not related to aircraft purchase) is included in administration overheads. In effect, not only is interest treated as a cost of airline operations, but the accounting treatment also effectively conceals the level of interest charged to the company's profit and loss account in any year.
The next paragraph states:
The Inquiry noted that TAA's treatment of interest differs in a number of respects from conventional accounting practice.

I say that simply to show that I am not the only one who is making comments about these aspects to which I wish to refer; the Holcroft committee also made some comments. I want to do it not by way of attack. I have great respect for the general efficiency of the way both airlines produce a good service at what, in comparable costs with the rest of the world, is a remarkably low fare for the standard of service which is provided. People insist that the airlines are deficient and that there is cross-subsidisation, that fare costs are high and so on, but if we are to look at these questions, and I do not say that we should not, then let us look at the figures and identify what is really happening before we start to debate things such as air fare formulas. The problems with the fact that TAA is a statutory authority rather than a public company structured under the Companies Act include the fact that employment conditions-in particular, superannuation-impose an intolerable burden, as described by its Chairman in the most recent report. The chairman on page 8 of the 1979-80 annual report stated:
The cost of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme is of such magnitude that no enterprise could remain self-sufficient in a competitive environment with such a handicap.
A little earlier the chairman said:

While the Australian Government Actuary has not completed any evaluation of the fund beyond 30 June 1976 we believe that the $96.228m by which the actuarial liability was reported to be uncovered at that date would now have increased to a figure approaching $140m.

That is a debt due by and in respect of the operation of one half of our domestic airlines. That is a debt which has been accruing for the past seven years and which has now built up to $140m or nearly ten times the figure identified by Senator Button as the total amount of capital invested in the operation by the Government. I am not saying this as a matter of blame but to identify a fact. It is a liability which the Government now proposes should be paid for-at least as to some amount over $90m-by the taxpayers of Australia. Why should the taxpayers of Australia have to pick up the tab for the extra cost which airline passengers are not providing and which the airline system cannot provide because-according to the chairman of Trans-Australia Airlines-it is a provision which would put the airlines out of business if they charged fares in relation to the real cost of conducting their operation? What is the reason for this cost? The reason is that it is a statutory authority subject to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme instead of being a public company which could organise its own superannuation scheme in the same way as ATI. This would cost something like the 7.8 per cent or 8 per cent employer contribution which ATI makes to its employees superannuation scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason comes back to this Parliament, doesn't it?

—I think a lot of the blame should come here. This is why I raise the matter. It is a matter for us to consider. I wish to emphasise again that I am not criticising TAA. I am criticising aspects of its structure and operation. I am trying to identify some effects of this. I would like to go through some of the other points.
—Does that have any implications in other areas of the Public Service?

—That has very extensive implications in other areas of the Public Service and statutory authorities, particularly bearing in mind that two out of three of the total number of people employed by the Commonwealth in direct government activities or in its statutory authorities are employed in statutory authorities. I think that is a matter for another debate. I will now go on to the matter of gearing and the impact of that on the figures. Senator Button may be interested in this matter because it is why I was curious when he said we would be pleased to know that the fund had only $15m capital invested. The net result of having a low invested capital, low equity and a high gearing ratio, which obtains for TAA,-ATI attains that benefit as does Qantas Airways Ltd, the Australian National Line and a number of other enterprises in Australia because they receive government guarantee-is that the comparability of their published profit figures and the tax they pay is totally distorted because, instead of having a profit figure out of which eventually capital is serviced by way of dividend, before the profit figure and tax figure, interest payments are taken off as expenditure. That is the simple net result of having a high gearing ratio. So, a double advantage is given by that. The first advantage is that there is an operation which can be conducted on a very low, or relatively low, capital base and a high loan content because of government guarantee. The second advantage is that a benefit is given by reducing the net taxation to be paid because they can take off the cost of servicing a large section of the total capital out of profit before tax instead of after tax.

SPEECH.PARA: What this means is that where these government enterprises, in particular, are obtaining these sorts of high gearing government guarantee benefits the taxation which they pay is unreal and the profit which is disclosed is an unreal profit. I do not have enough time to elaborate on that but I do not think it needs elaboration to most honourable senators to see what impact it can have. When the complication of superannuation is added to that-it is not provided for at all-there is no provision and nor has there been provision in recent years by TAA for superannuation. This again produces an unreal figure because one would have expected the companies to have made some provision for it. Yet, if one goes through the accounts there is no provision for superannuation. Apparently the taxpayer is expected to pay that. When one comes to the question of depreciation and depreciation policies it is interesting to find that the Auditor-General has done something about which I have been commenting for some years. He has now required TAA to change its depreciation policy because it, and one or two other of the Commonwealth statutory authorities, have engaged in depreciation policies which are totally unreal. I will read from page 9 of the report of Trans-Australia Airlines a statement which I think makes the point I want to make. It states:

One significant change of accounting policy was made, in that capitalised exchange losses on foreign borrowings are now amortised over the remaining terms of the relevant loans, instead of over the remaining estimated economic lives of the aircraft financed. It is also noted, although it did not strictly constitute a change of accounting policy, that the Commission extended the economic lives of all aircraft types except the Twin-Otter, and adopted aircraft residual values of 10 per cent instead of the previous nil values, for depreciation purposes. In implementing these revised depreciation assumptions, the Commission re-stated accumulated aircraft depreciation provisions to the levels that would have existed if the new assumptions had been applied from the outset, this treatment being demanded by the Auditor-General .

I will identify the effect that that has had. This year it has meant that TAA has put in what would be regarded by most people as a rather miserable return. I am not saying it is the fault of TAA. There may be other reasons which we need to identify. But for a total operation, for which there is a total revenue of $378.5m, to turn in a net profit of $2.9m would be rather poor in the estimation of most people. I think that most shareholders, if they were shareholders in a company which had a total turnover of nearly $400m and had a net profit of under $3m, would start to ask questions at the next annual meeting or else would sell their shares. Let us identify the fact that as a result of this change in depreciation policy that profit has been taken up from about $2m to just under $3m. In fact, the only reason that the figure gets up to $3m is as a result of the change in the depreciation policy. That is only a little change rather than a big change which has been made because, as the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares points out, and as I have attempted to point out over the years, the whole depreciation policy being used is a failure. Assets, that is land and buildings have not been revalued since 1974. Assets values in relation to aircraft are these incredibly depreciated values where the life was estimated and depreciated down to nil. Now, because TAA has had difficulty in making a profit this year it did what Ansett did two years before when it suffered a huge loss of $18m in relation to Associated Securities Ltd. It revalued its aircraft. It is not something peculiar to either ATI or TAA. The only thing is that Ansett had to do this a couple of years earlier. Now, TAA has done it. The result is still that there is no real revaluation of assets, only a little change in depreciation policy which means that the profit can be boosted a little bit this year. If the assets of TAA were revalued on a proper basis I imagine they would be sufficient to go a very long way toward covering the indebtedness of $140m in respect of superannuation. One of the things that I have suggested in the past-I am getting to the stage of believing it must be insisted upon-is that before we determine any further questions about what will happen in relation to the domestic airlines, we should start to get some real figures from both of the protected domestic airlines on their actual operating expenses and their real asset values, and not some of the nonsense that we have been getting to deal with.

I do not want to delay the proceedings of the Senate but let me just identify a few other problems which seem to me to warrant further explanation than they receive. An extraordinary item in both senses of the word-in the accounting sense and in the ordinary language sense-is the one referred to in note 11 to the present annual report-the provision for annual leave. In the past five years TAA has had a net profit of $17m. Let me look at one item which relates to only two of those years. For two years, for some reason which is not explained, TAA decided to make provision for annual leave-something which is not done by public companies as far as I can gather. I have looked through a large number of reports and I have searched with a large number of people, but I cannot find such a provision. For some reason TAA made special provision for accumulated annual leave which is a nice way of setting aside an amount of money out of profit before having to declare it as part of the profit on which a dividend will be paid. Over two years, the year ending 1978 and the year ending 1979, it made a provision of nearly $11m. Unless that can be explained in a much better way than it has been explained in any of the reports which have been produced to date, my impression-and from checking this out, the impression of a number of people-would be that that is another aspect of hidden profitability. One is tempted to believe that TAA, during a period of some stress in relation to its indebtedness for superannuation, has been happily tucking away wherever it can whatever fat it can to ensure that it has hidden assets or funds which eventually it can draw upon. The sooner it draws upon them, the sooner they will become identified and the sooner we will know the real situation.

I come back to this point: Is it really fair that the taxpayers of Australia should have to pick up a bill for $90m or $140m for superannuation benefits for the employees of an airline which is supposed to be in a competitive situation in what some people might think is a free enterprise land of competition but which others criticise as being no real competition but a protected duopolistic situation? Let me refer to some other items. There is the problem involving interest which I have referred to already and also this problem: There is no way from the published data in which one could attempt to rewrite the accounts of TAA on a normal commercial basis. I have had a considerable amount of work done to try to restructure them so that they can be compared in a way which would enable one to find out whether TAA is operating efficiently, whether it is making a profit, whether it is making a large profit or a small profit and what its real costs are. From the published data that is not possible.

I have made the general criticisms that in short there are problems in relation to the way in which interest has been dealt with, in relation to depreciation-both of those being extremely abnormal things-and in relation to annual leave which in the absence of any better explanation, is an extraordinary thing. There is also a problem in relation to valuation and revaluation of assets which again puts one in a position of not knowing their real value. However, when one looks at the aircraft involved and at the depreciation which has been applied, one can come to the conclusion that there are tens of millions of dollars worth, if not more than $100m worth, of assets which do not appear in their rightful amounts in the financial statements which are prepared as the result of the policy-it is applied by other statutory authorities; I am not suggesting TAA is the only one-of depreciating the assets to a nil value over their anticipated life expectancy and including in that depreciation the amount in respect of interest owing on the loan which can then-one cannot tell from the accounts whether it does-also amount to a double deduction from profitability of interest paid. The asset is depreciated and also apparently a deduction is made within the accounts as a payment out so that there is a double impact,

Having summarised some of those problems of interest, the gearing ratios, the lack of comparability that arises as a result of the extraordinary gearing ratios that are applied, depreciation, the extraordinary item for annual leave which, subject to any explanation, seems to be a way of tucking away a little of what would otherwise be profit and the huge liability in respect of superannuation, all I can say is that it seems to me that we need to request TAA to prepare accounts which indicate what the real costs are. If we had those we could then look not only at TAA and how its operation could be made most efficient but also at how the real cost of air fares in Australia could be identified. What are the real costs when airlines prepare their accounts on the sort of basis that I have identified? I have picked out only a few of the more outstanding items. There are plenty of others. I am reminded of the fact that three years ago, I think, I identified in a speech in this chamber a discrepancy between two years in the accounts of TAA of an amount which from recollection was about $400,000. To this day that has never been explained or corrected. I just wonder at an organisation which can make such a mistake and blithely ignore it from then on. There may be a perfectly simple explanation, but it would have helped if TAA had identified the explanation at some stage in its accounts.

My time is running short. I was going to discuss very briefly the suggestion made by the Australian Democrats that we should look at the amalgamation of TAA and Qantas Airways Ltd. I agree that we should look at that question, but bigness is not necessarily efficiency. I also believe that totally different considerations may apply to the operation of an international airline under international agreements and against international competition than ought to apply to a domestic airline. Not all economies can be achieved from combination, as the United Kingdom's experience of attempted amalgamation has shown.

I thank the Senate for giving me the opportunity to speak briefly on this matter tonight. I indicate that there are drawers full of more information in relation to this question for anybody who is interested at any time in pursuing the debate about how the accounts might be prepared so that they are on a basis which would give people who are interested an opportunity to identify the real profits and losses, the real asset values and the real costs of operation of our domestic airlines. Until we do that I think we are blowing hot air and not flying the people through the air efficiently. We should have this information before we start debating air fare formulas when we do not know accurately the basis on which they may have been calculated.
