DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Kapunda Committee for the Ageing Inc.-Transfer of Land to the New South Wales Government

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., in accordance with the sessional order relating to the adjournment of the Senate, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter tonight which I first raised in the Senate on 29 August 1979. That is the matter of Government funding to the Kapunda Committee for Ageing Inc. to enable that Committee to construct at Kapunda an aged persons hostel. After reading Press reports on Saturday, I am very confused as to what the Government actually is doing about providing funds to this Committee. Back in 1978, the Chairman of that Committee, Dr David Jones, wrote under the date 28 March to the Department of Social Security. I will quote not the whole of the letter but only part of it so that honourable senators will have the history of this application. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Sir,
As your Department will be soon considering the allocation of funds for the 1979-80 year, I wish to renew and reinforce the application by our committee for the Aged in Kapunda.

Having visited Kapunda during 1979 and spoken to people whom I know there, I received a letter from Dr Jones. I will quote only the last paragraph of the letter dated 17 August 1979 which sets out the problems the Committee was faced with. The letter states:
Would you be kind enough to plead our case with the Minister for Social Security and seek their support.

That is, seek the support of the Department. On 27 August, just 10 days later, I wrote to Senator Guilfoyle in her capacity as Minister for Social Security and asked whether she would give urgent consideration to the application from the Kapunda Committee for the Ageing. I also wrote to Dr Jones in a letter under the same date advising him that I had approached the Minister.

On 29 August, when I was speaking in the Senate in the debate on Budget Papers I referred to funding for aged persons' homes and I raised with the Minister the matter of funding for a home for the aged people of Kapunda. I referred her to the statement she had made on 21 August on social security programs under the heading 'Assistance to the Aged' and the amount of money that the Government would be making available. Time went by and, on 21 September, I received a letter from the Minister, Senator Guilfoyle. I will quote the pertinent part of that letter in which she said:
In view of the existing commitments outlined above--
She had set out in the letter the reasons why things could not be done and the amount of money which had been allocated to various other projects-

you will appreciate that I am unable to give any assurance of funding for a particular new project at this time. I can assure you, however, that my department has recorded details of the Committee's proposal and it will receive careful consideration when relative priorities are re-examined in the context of future allocations of Government funds for the aged persons' accommodation program.
The letter concluded with these words:
I commend the Committee on its excellent efforts to promote the establishment of its proposed hostel units and I regret that I am unable to provide the assistance which has been sought at this time.
That assistance had been sought for quite a few years previously. I then wrote to Dr Jones under the date 10 October. I said:
I regret that the Minister in her answer does not give any indication that you will receive assistance in the near future.
You may be assured that I will keep reminding the Minister of your needs.
I enclosed with that letter a copy of Senator Guilfoyle's letter.
On 18 December 1979, Senator Guilfoyle issued a Press statement headed 'Major New $225m Program for Aged and Disabled Persons' Accommodation'. That Press release stated:
The Commonwealth Government announced today a new $225 million program for aged and disabled persons' accommodation.

I will not quote the whole of the Press release because I think the contents are already in Hansard. On 20 December, I sent an urgent telegram to the Minister asking her, in view of that statement, to place the Kapunda Home for Ageing high on the priority list. I have not received a reply. Of course, last year on the first day the Senate sat-Tuesday, 19 February 1980-I spoke in the adjournment debate, as I am doing now, on behalf of the people at Kapunda and I put the case to the Minister. I thought I had put it fairly strongly. I again raised the matter two days later in the adjournment debate on 21 February. I said:

Tonight, after dinner, I was very pleased to be approached by the Minister and to be told that she had now made available the money for the Kapunda Committee for the Ageing. When I rang the people in Kapunda after receiving the message they were overjoyed. I take the opportunity tonight to pay tribute to the Minister for her very prompt action in dealing with the matter after I raised it during the adjournment debate. I think this shows that there is some value in making speeches on the adjournment.
The letter that I received from the Minister dated 21 February, after she had spoken to me personally in the corridor, in part stated:

Although the Kapunda Committee's proposal was not included in the initial 1980-81 approvals, a further assessment of the proposal has now been made and I am pleased to advise that the proposal has been given an approval-in-principle for funding in 1980-81. I would suggest the Committee provide the Director of my department in Adelaide with firm details of its proposal as soon as possible. This will enable the Director to give whatever advice and assistance he can.
I sent a copy of that letter to the Chairman of the Committee, Dr Jones.

Prior to that request from the Minister, full details of what the Committee wanted to do had already been given to the Department of Social Security but further details were sent to it. I received no further communication from either Senator Guilfoyle or the present Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, from the date of that letter, 21 February 1980. However, I was very astounded to read in the Adelaide Advertiser of last Saturday, 7 March, an article headed 'Unit cash approved'. The article reads:
KAPUNDA-A $262,035 Federal grant towards building 20 hostel units for the aged in Nash Street has been approved.
It has been made under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act in favor of the Kapunda Committee for Ageing Inc.
The Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, has told the MHR for Wakefield, Mr Giles, of the grant.

Senator Chaney has told Mr Giles eight months after I was advised by the then Minister, Senator Guilfoyle, that this money was available. I made the initial approaches. I feel that Senator Chaney has displayed some discourtesy to me in that, since the money was made available, there has been no communication to me unless this is an extra grant.

I can see a frown on the face of my colleague from South Australia-I have forgotten his name-Senator Messner. This may be another grant, an extra grant. I will be pleased if it is. What I really am concerned and confused about is that, having been told personally by the previous Minister for Social Security that after I had made the application the money had been approved, having received a letter that the money was approved and having advised the people in Kapunda that their request had been approved, I found last Saturday a report of Senator Chaney announcing through the local Liberal member that a grant had been made.

I hope that Senator Messner can clear up the matter tonight for me and the people of Kapunda by indicating what is going on and why I was ignored in the giving of the announcement to Mr Giles although I was the one who made the initial approach, I was the one who stood in this Parliament and thanked Senator Guilfoyle for making the money available and, as I said, no further communication has been received by me since 21 February last year until I picked up the Advertiser on Saturday and saw the report that the grant has been made available. It is confusing not only to me but also to the people in Kapunda who alerted me to it and who have worked very hard in an endeavour to get hostel units for the aged people who live in Kapunda. I hope that Senator Messner can throw some light on the story tonight because, if he cannot, I will pursue the matter further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The eloquence of Senator McLaren forces me to take part in this debate. I want to reinforce the argument he has put by speaking in the context of events in New South Wales. Honourable senators will know that I have always been a crusader for the transfer of Commonwealth-occupied land to the premier State, New South Wales. During the last Federal elections there was strong agitation for the land occupied by the Abbotsford quarantine station to be transferred to the New South Wales Government. I received a letter on this subject from the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman, who pointed out that the accepted practice-I emphasise the words 'accepted practice'-was for this land, which had been acquired in World War I, to be returned to New South Wales only at the current market value. The State Government, which, like all other State governments, has been affected by a reduction in Federal grants, has had to economise. The State Government has considered the idea of the Housing Commission of New South Wales taking half of the land and making the other half available as a waterfront picnic area on the Parramatta River. It is an area which Senator Davidson, who is from the same State as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), would well know because part of the inquiry of the Senate Select Committee on Water Pollution in the 1970s traversed that river; so I am sure that the Minister has got the message.

SPEECH.PARA: What is so reprehensible about this matter-I use the word 'reprehensible' advisedly-is that I was told by Mr Newman that he had put it to the New South Wales Government that it had to come up with hard cash but, to my amazement, out of the blue-of course, it was election time and I am a resident of the Lowe electorate-a former Prime Minister, the right honourable member for Lowe (Sir William McMahon), was able to say: 'The Minister has used his discretion. The land has been handed over to the New South Wales Government for use as a park. The Commonwealth is waiving any monetary consideration'. As a Conservationist I welcome any addition to parkland, but I think an important precedent is being set.

When Senator McLaren was speaking previously I interjected that we are all supposed to be equal. On one occasion I had a heated altercation with Sir John Gorton, before he became Prime Minister. He said: 'Senator, we are all equal in this Parliament'. He used the word 'Parliament' for both Houses. I have never received a letter from Mr Newman confirming that the Federal Government had granted to the New South Wales Government this prime river frontage as a park and confirming that the financial compensation for the value of the land had been waived. Whatever dialogue ensued between Senator McLaren and Senator Chaney, an insult was paid to New South Wales senators. I still have not had a letter from Mr Newman. I pioneered the agitation in this matter. I have not been told the official reason for this happening. I do not cavil at the decision, but I represent New South Wales and I was entitled to be told the decision of the Government at the same time as Sir William McMahon was told. I ask the Minister to see that this miscarriage of justice is rectified and that I get a letter of apology from the responsible Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to Senator Mulvihill and my colleague, Senator Chaney, will respond to Senator what's-his-name-Senator McLaren-shortly. I take on board the point raised by Senator Mulvihill. I will undertake to refer the matter to Mr Newman and see whether I can get some information which might satisfy him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am tempted to say that I want to respond to Senator what's-his-name from wherever-it-is, but, since he is complaining about my lack of courtesy, I will be more polite than that. Unfortunately I heard only part of what Senator McLaren had to say. By the time I got to the chamber the Press release to which he referred had gone to Hansard, so all I can say at this stage is that I am a little uncertain as to the basis of the complaint of discourtesy that he has levelled in this matter. With respect to applications for subsidies for aged and disabled persons' housing, the general situation is that my Department and the Minister for the time being tend to receive multiple representations from a series of senators and members. Very often one has a number of senators from a State as well as the local member of the House of Representatives concerned about their constituents' interests. In the case raised by the honourable senator it is very likely, I think, that there were representations from a number of senators from both sides of the chamber. The fact that it would appear that a Press release was put out relatively recently by the local member of the House of Representatives is, again, not unusual, particularly when the funding has yet to come through. I understand that to be the case. I am lost for words. I do not intend to say any more. I assure the Senate that no discourtesy would have been intended by my Department or by me in dealings with Senator McLaren or any other senator. I am sure that there is a perfectly innocent explanation for the matters he is so excited about.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 27 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were any Barrier Reef islands included on the Australian Heritage Commission's listings for the National Estate; if so, how many.
(2) Were any Barrier Reef islands excluded from the listings; if so, (a) how many; and (b) why were these islands excluded.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) All islands and parts of islands which are either declared Queensland National Parks or owned by the Commonwealth within the Great Barrier Reef Region as defined in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, as amended, were entered in the Register of the National Estate on 8 July 1980. There are approximately 200 islands or parts of islands in the above categories.
(2) Yes.

(a) The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has advised that the total number of reef islands is not known at present but a survey is now being carried out which will provide this information. Thus it is not possible to be precise about the number of islands in the Region not included in the Register.

(b) The Australian Heritage Commission originally publicly proposed that all islands in the Region should be included in the Register. After consideration of objections to this proposal and having reviewed the available information, it was subsequently decided to include only those islands in (1) above, as a first step, until evidence on the national estate significance of the remaining islands could be obtained.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has a letter been sent to video access centres funded by the Australian Film Commission, indicating that they should not rely on any funding from the Commission beyond 30 June 1981.
(2) Is it intended to cut off all funding from that date; if not, from what source does the Minister expect funding to come after June 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) I have been advised that the Australian Film Commission is to re-examine the future of video centres with a view to-
(a) their cost effectiveness and their potential to increase revenue from other sources;
(b) whether or not the Commission is the appropriate authority to handle their funding;
(c) whether other authorities may be more appropriate funding sources and would be prepared to take over funding responsibility.
The Commission has asked video centres to submit three year plans for future operations.

I have been further advised that the Commission considers that the time is appropriate to review the operations of the video scheme which was launched in 1973 by the then Film, Radio and Television Board of the Australia Council. As a community experiment, it was based largely on the concept of supplying black and white 1/2 inch video equipment to members of the public, particularly those in disadvantaged areas of the community. The equipment supplied is at the end of is working life and such equipment is no longer manufactured.
The Commission is looking at the question of whether it should provide more capital investment to boost the centres or whether the program should be reduced or eliminated.
A decision on the level of support for the video centres in 1981-82 will be taken in the context of the forthcoming Budget deliberations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 5 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were veterans diagnosed as suffering from pulmonary tuberculosis assured for many years that their pension would continue subject to further review, but would not under any circumstances be reduced below the ordinary total rate prescribed by the Act, and did a letter from the Deputy Commissioner, Victorian Branch, Repatriation Commission, dated 8 April 1941, confirm this undertaking.
(2) Did the Senate Standing Committee on Health and Welfare in its Report of 1973, support the preservation of benefits already gained in the interests of ex-servicemen.

(3) Did Mr Justice Toose's report dated June 1975 (page 25, paragraph 121) recommend that pensions, under section 27 (1) of the Act, for pulmonary tuberculosis should be continued with the present rate, and that future entitlement for pulmonary tuberculosis should be at an assured minimum rate at or about 25 per cent of the present general rate.

(4) Does the freezing of pulmonary tuberculosis pensions at 1978 figures, subject to continuing re-assessment of percentage disability, dishonour the above undertakings and reject the above recommendations; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have seen copies of some letters which were sent out many years ago by Deputy Commissioners of my Department, advising individual veterans that their pension would not be reduced below the then applicable 100 per cent General Rate. However, I am not aware of any assurances given to these veterans that the minimum level of this pension would be raised with increases in the 100 per cent General Rate, although in practice this did occur until 1978.

(2) The Senate Standing Committee on Health and Welfare, in its report of 1973, did not fully support the preservation of benefits already gained in the interests of ex-servicemen and, in fact, recommended a number of changes. In particular, recommendation 19 called for the repeal of section 37 of the Repatriation Act 1920. Section 37 of the Act provided that disability pension granted in respect of pulmonary tuberculosis would not be less than the 100 per cent General Rate at the time of grant.

(3) In his report of June 1975, Mr Justice Toose recommended that pensions in payment under section 37 of the Repatriation Act 1920 for tuberculosis be continued at the minimum rate then applicable and that future grants should only be assessed at about 25 per cent of the General Rate but with higher rates payable as applicable. His Honour also recommended that section 37 (3) of the Act be amended as there was no longer any justification for automatic grant of war pension for pulmonary tuberculosis.

(4) The changes to the legislation are not considered to be contrary to either the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Health and Welfare or those of Mr Justice Toose. The repeal of section 37 of the Repatriation Act 1920 was raised by the Senate Committee in 1973 but it was only after long and careful consideration that the Government decided there was no longer sufficient reason for the rate of pension in respect of pulmonary tuberculosis to be assessed on any grounds other than those of actual incapacity.

Legislation introduced by the Government was more lenient than the recommendations of the Senate Committee and, although not accepting that veterans granted entitlement for pulmonary tuberculosis in the future be assured a minimum pension, the pensions in payment were continued at a rate higher than that recommended by Mr Justice Toose. The changes to the legislation were in accordance with his recommendations that each case which arises in future be dealt with on its merits.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Did a Mr Anthony Bruce Catip White-Australia attempt to nominate for the 1974 Senate election in Queensland; if so, was his nomination not accepted, and if so, for what reason.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The position in relation to the matter raised in the question is as follows: On 29 April 1974 a Mr Anthony Bruce Catip sought to nominate for the 1974 Senate election in Queensland as Anthony Bruce Catip White-Australia. The then Australian Electoral Officer for Queensland acting on the basis of legal advice from the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department, rejected that nomination as it did not comply with the requirements of section 71 (a) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, in that, the nomination form did not contain the true christian names and surname of the person nominated.
On 18 May 1974 Mr Catip filed a petition in the Court of Disputed Returns challenging the validity of the rejection of his nomination. Mr Catip did not serve or otherwise proceed with the petition.
Subsequently in 1975 and again in 1980 Mr Catip nominated for, and contested, the Senate election in Queensland as Anthony Bruce Catip.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 5 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the President of the Repatriation Review Tribunal determine whether an appellant's costs to the Federal Court should be borne by the Crown.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The provisions relating to payment of costs in respect of appeals to the Federal Court, arising from proceedings before the Repatriation Review Tribunal, are set out in section 107VZZK of the Repatriation Act 1920 which provides that, where an appeal is instituted by the Repatriation Commission, the approved costs of the veteran shall be borne by the Commonwealth. Where an appeal to the Federal Court is instituted by a veteran, the Federal Court has a discretion to make such order as to the costs in the appeal as it considers just.
The President of the Repatriation Review Tribunal has no authority in the matter of determination of responsibility for costs in respect of appeals to the Federal Court.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What form does protocol take for the presentation of credentials and the playing of the Australian and the home nations' national anthems, when an Australian Ambassador operating from one embassy post has to service other adjacent countries.

(2) Is provision made at such ceremonies for the home nation's band to have a copy of Advance Australia Fair or have we on occasions reneged on our national responsibilities and played 'God Save the Queen' despite the convincing majority recorded in a national referendum to select the former tune as the national anthem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The ceremonial for the presentation of credentials by incoming Australian Ambassadors abroad to the Head of State of the country to which they are accredited is not uniform and varies from country to country. In some countries national anthems are played; in others this is not customary.

(2) It was decided in May 1976 that as a constant practice Advance Australia Fair should be the musical salute played at ceremonies for the presentation of credentials by Australian Ambassadors abroad. This Ministerial direction still stands. Australian missions have been directed to ensure that the home nation's band has a copy of the score of Advance Australia Fair for these occasions.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 December 1980 (Hansard, page 273) Senator Teague asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, without notice, a question concerning budgetary problems within the Australian National University, with particular reference to the topics of superannuation and energy.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Education has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Tertiary Education Commission is examining the present superannuation arrangements of all Australian universities and colleges of advanced education, and will be including comment on the matter in Volume 1 of its 'Report for 1982-84 Triennium' which is expected to be available shortly. Grants for non-salary items of expenditure which include fuel are supplemented annually in accordance with a national index maintained by the Tertiary Education Commission. In this way, the base grant for total operating expenditure is adjusted to maintain its real value. To this extent, universities are compensated for increases in the cost of fuel, although it is recognised that annual supplementation may not fully meet cost increases as they occur progressively throughout the year. This matter will also be taken into consideration by the Tertiary Education Commission in the preparation of its 'Report for 1982-84 Triennium'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 December 1980 (Hansard, page 272) Senator Kilgariff asked me a question, without notice, concerning the intentions of the Australian National Railways Commission to retain a section of the old narrow gauge railway to Alice Springs.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Chairman of the Australian National Railways Commission met with the Ghan Preservation Society at Alice Springs in November 1980. The Chairman indicated that the MacDonnell to Ewaninga section would not be demolished, pending negotiations with the Society. Negotiations for the retention of this section and the provision of assets, including rollingstock, are proceeding between the Commission and the Society.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 November 1980 (Hansard, page 106) Senator Robertson asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, without notice, a question concerning the admission to Australia of East Timorese.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Nominations in favour of over 1,000 East Timorese have so far been received under the special humanitarian program arrangements announced on 7 October 1980 and processing of these in the State offices of my Department is going forward rapidly. It is expected that the majority of the nominations will be acceptable under the relaxed criteria established in respect of this program. Satisfactory nominations are being forwarded overseas as quickly as possible and processing of applications is being expedited at the overseas posts.
Two families approved under this program have already arrived in Australia and I expect that movement will shortly gain momentum and continue well into 1981.

You have asked also about allegations that Timorese wishing to leave Indonesia are required to pay bribes of $1,000 before being permitted to depart. We have received some reports of claimed malpractice in relation to the grant of exit permits to Timorese seeking to emigrate. These reports have been brought to the attention of the Indonesian authorities by the Australian Embassy in Jakarta, with expressions of official concern.
